loans.name: Margarita's Group

texts.en: Margarita A.'s main source of income comes from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. She is 58 years old, married and has four adult children. She is from the village of Allinguigan 3rd, Ilagan, Isabela. Margarita has been in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. Margarita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Margarita has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI which was used to purchase materials to make furniture. Margarita is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. Margarita is the leader of a 20 member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Margarita A. Group". About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Billy

texts.en:
Billy M. is from the village of Naawan, Misamis Oriental. He is 34 years old. Billy is married. To make a living, Billy owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services to transport passengers in the local community. Billy has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Billy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Billy is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Billy from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza B. is from the village of Kiwalan, Iligan City. Liza is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Liza sells "ukay-ukay" or used clothes, in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education.

loans.name: Fifamè Nadège

texts.fr: K. Fifamè Nadège est née en 1982 à Djèrègbé, à quelques kilomètres de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Fifamè Nadège vit toujours dans ce quartier. Mariée à BALOGOUN Daniel un mécanicien, Fifamè Nadège est mère d'un enfant qui est scolarisé. Mais Fifamè Nadège vit seule avec son enfant et assure seule les charges de son enfant. Fifamè Nadège n'a fait que l'école primaire. Après son échec, Fifamè Nadège a appris la coiffure, une activité qu'elle mène depuis 5 ans et qui lui permet de se prendre en charge et d'assurer ses différentes charges. Fifamè Nadège vend également dans son atelier, des mèches et des produits de cheveux, ce qui lui pemet d'avoir plusieurs sources de revenu. C'est au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo, que Fifamè Nadège s'approvisionne. Fifamè Nadège a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Fifamè Nadège souhaite augmenter son fonds de roulement et agrandir son activité, ce qui lui permettra de mieux satisfaire ses clients. C'est ce qui conduit Fifamè Nadège à solliciter un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Fifamè Nadège K. was born in 1982 in Djèrègbé, a few kilometers from Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She is still living in this area. Married to Daniel BALOGOUN, a mechanic, Fifamè Nadège is mother of one child who is attending school. However, she lives alone with her child, and is its sole provider. Fifamè Nadège has attended school at the primary level. Following her personal difficulties, Fifamè Nadège learned hairdressing, an activity she has exercised for five years and has allowed her to take charge of herself and of her various expenses. In her beauty salon, she also sells hair extensions and hair products, which provides her with another source of income. She gets her supplies from the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. Fifamè Nadège has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, which she has repaid in full. Given the continuous increase in customer demand, she wants to add to her working capital and expand her business. This will allow her to better satisfy her customers. For this reason Fifamè Nadège is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy hair extensions and hair products

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel N. is thirty nine years old, is married and has two children. His business is located at Umoja 1, a residential area in Nairobi which is inhabited by middle-class people.

Samuel is involved in property management and serves the tenants in Umoja 1 estate. He has done this business for seven years and he is determined to make it grow. In fact, he wants to be a real estate owner in the future.

Samuel tries to manage customers who are not able to make payments to him as per their agreement; e.g. some clients are not able to pay rent which to Samuel is a challenge to his business.

Samuel is using his Kes 50,000 loan to buy office furniture to be able to run his business in the comfort of a nice office. Samuel also has a transport business. He is a very optimistic person.

loans.use: To buy office furniture

To make a living, Priscilla owns and operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. Priscilla has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Priscilla joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Priscilla is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Priscilla from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. loans.name: Isabelle Fifamè

texts.fr: Née en 1960 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, H. Isabelle Fifamè vit depuis 15 ans environs au quartier Dowa, dans le cinquième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Isabelle Fifamè est mariée à GBETOHO Jacques. Le couple a cinq enfants et un autre enfant à charge. Mais seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Dowa. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. N'ayant jamais été à l'école, Isabelle Fifamè vend des condiments de sauce (tomates fraîches, oignons, piments, etc.)au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo. Isabelle Fifamè mène cette activité depuis environs 5 ans, une activité qui lui génère de revenu qu'elle utilise pour l'agrandir et subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants. Isabelle Fifamè se ravitaille au Nigéria, pays limitrophe du Bénin. Isabelle Fifamè a obtenu deux fois de crédits auprès de ALIDé, et ces deux crédits ont été tous bien remboursés. Face à la concurrence qui sévit sur ce marché, Isabelle Fifamè désire renforcer davantage son activité et mieux attirer les clients. Mais Isabelle Fifamè manque de moyens financiers pour y arriver. C'est ce qui amène Isabelle Fifamè à solliciter un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1960 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, Isabelle Fifamè H. has lived for around 15 years in the Dowa neighborhood of the fifth arrondissement or district of the town of Porto-Novo. Isabelle Fifamè is married to Jacques GBETOHO.The couple have five children of their own and another child in their care. But only certain of the children are at school. The family lives together in Dowa. The couple take responsibility together for the household expenses. Having never been to school, Isabelle Fifamè sells condiments for sauces (fresh tomatoes, onions, chili peppers etc.) at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. She has been carrying out this activity for around five years, and it generates income which she uses to expand the business and meet her children's needs. Isabelle Fifamè gets fresh supplies in Nigeria, a country which borders on Bénin. She has had two loans from ALIDé and both were repaid without incident. In view of the ruthless competition in this market, Isabelle Fifamè would like to strengthen her business and be able to attract her clients more easily. However, she lacks the financial means to do this and for this reason is applying for a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of baskets of fresh tomatoes, onions and chili peppers

loans.name: Sevilla

texts.en:
Sevilla D. is 28 years old. She is married, and they have been given of an only daughter.

Sevilla joined ASHI in 2009 because she wanted to have her own business since her husband's income is not enough to sustain the daily needs of their family. She will use her starting capital of Php 5,000 for the vending of frozen foods.

Sevilla and her husband aim to use ASHI loans to develop a stable business so they can save for the education of their only child and have their own home someday. She is optimistic and strong enough to face the challenge of poverty.

loans.use: To buy frozen foods

loans.name: Zarb Ali Group

texts.en:
This pictured group's name is 'Zarb A.' group, and it is made up of two members. They would like to receive a group loan of 20000 Afghani.

Abdull Hakim, 35, is the group leader. He is married with 7 children. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan, and he has a metal-working shop in the same area as his house. With this loan he wants to enlarge his shop and buy some tools for his metal working. He is the only one who has to manage to support the household and the family members.

The second member of 'Zarb A.' group is Shafiqa who wants to use her loan to purchase a new sewing machine and cloth for her tailoring business. They are both happy that their businesses can progress because of this loan process of Kiva's.

loans.use: to buy necessary things for their businesses

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan has been farming since 1997.  She and her husband have been patiently tilling their rice field to generate an income for the family. They now have four children, the oldest of whom is 13. 

Susan wants increase their earnings by doubling their harvest.  She applied for a loan from CEVI to help her maintain the farm. She is asking for 7,000 Philippine pesos to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita M. is from the village of Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old. Teresita is widowed and has 7 adult children. Teresita owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $107 US) for these activities.

In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Teresita is requesting her first loan, for 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en: Elisa ventured into farming in 2006. She recently joined CEVI, an MFI, to expand her business opportunities. As a married woman with two children, she has to make an income to sustain her family. She is now preparing her land farm for planting. She needs farm inputs so she applied for a loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos. With this amount, Elisa will be able to purchase farm supplies like seeds, fertilizers, and more.

loans.use: Farm inputs like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en: Elsie tends 2.5 hectares of rice field. She is 46 years old, married and has three children. Aside from farming, she also has a hog-raising business. She  joined CEVI, an MFI, to help her business financially. She chose this MFI because of its low interest rate. She is now requesting 7,000 Philippine pesos. She will use this loan for farm supplies and pig feed.

loans.use: Farm supplies and pig feed

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en: 20-year old Aileen has a two-year old child with her husband Robert. She invested in farming two years ago and is still actively doing this for a living. She said that because of her farm, she was able to start saving some money. She wants to maintain her farm and is now preparing it for planting. She has applied for a loan of 7, 000 Philippine pesos from Kiva field partner CEVI, which she will use to buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Jonaliza

texts.en:
Rice farming is what 28-year-old Jonaliza does for a living. She started farming in 2006. She also tried out hog-raising and still raises pigs.

Jonaliza wants to maintain her business involvement and also wants to improve her income. She currently needs farm inputs and feeds. She applied for a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI which she will use to buy seeds, fertilizer and pig feed.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and pig feed

loans.name: Epiphanie

texts.fr: Née en 1966 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, G. Epiphanie est mariée à FASSINOU Rigobert. Le couple a quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés et dont trois sont à leur charge. La famille vit ensemble au quartier Houinmè à Porto-Novo, depuis 5 ans environs. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Epiphanie a très peu fréquenté. Depuis près de 8 ans, Epiphanie mène comme activité la vente de divers produits (liqueurs, amuses gueule, eau minérale, savons de toilette et de lessive, etc.) dans sa boutique size à Catchi à Porto-Novo. Parallèlement à cette activité et de façon secondaire, Epiphanie vend des tissus, ce qui lui permet d'avoir plusieurs sources de revenus. C'est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Epiphanie s'approvisionne. Epiphanie a bénéficié une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Epiphanie ambitionne augmenter son fonds de roulement et élever davantage le niveau de son activité, pour mieux satisfaire ses clients. Mais actuellement Epiphanie éprouve de difficultés dans l’approvisionnement de ses produits. C'est la raison pour laquelle Epiphanie sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1966 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, Epiphanie G. is married to Rigobert FASSINOU. The couple has four children who are all at school; three of them are in their care. The family has been living together in the Houinmè district of Porto-Novo for about five years. The couple cover the household expenses between them. Epiphanie went to school very little. For almost eight years she has been carrying out a business selling various products (liqueurs, appetizers, mineral water, soaps and washing powder, etc.) in her shop in Catchi in Porto-Novo. At the same time Epiphanie has a secondary activity which is the sale of fabric; this allows her to have several sources of income. She stocks up at Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Epiphanie has had one loan from ALIDé, which she repaid without incident. Her ambition is to increase her working capital and raise her activity level in order to satisfy her customers better. But currently Epiphanie has difficulties getting supplies. This is the main reason she is applying for a second loan.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of diverse products (soaps, mineral water, appetizers, sugar)

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
63-year old Rogelio is a rice farmer. Despite his age, he is still strong enough to stand work on his farm.

Rogelio married his wife, Alicia, in 1972 and they now have grandchildren. He works hard so he can share his income with his children and grandchildren. He also wants to provide for their education.

Rogelio applied to CEVI for a loan of Php 7,000. He will use this loan to buy farm supplies and also pay the laborers who helped on the farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and to pay laborers who helped on the farm

loans.name: Exaltacion

texts.en: Exaltacion is a 59-year-old mother of two. She is married to Remgio. Both of them are farmers. She helps her husband cultivate their land for rice crops. She works hard to keep up with the growing needs in her household. She is currently in need of additional capital for her farm. She applied for a loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used for farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas K. O. is forty-two years old, married, and has four children. His wife is a businesswoman and they hope to give their children a good education. His business is located at Brick point-Nyamasaria in Kisumu. The business is situated along the Kisumu-Nairobi highway.

Before opening up the retail shop, Thomas was selling herbal medicine and to date he treats people using herbal medicines. He has for the last ten years been selling foodstuffs and general household goods, and he has even created employment for three people. He serves the area residents, passers-by, and school-going children.

Thomas acknowledges that he needs more space to serve a larger market. However he is using his Kes 50,000 loan to grow his business by adding more stocks of wheat flour and beans. In future, he hopes to set up a big clinic to help the sick through herbal medicines. He is courageous, bold, and simple.

loans.use: wheat flour and beans

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia has been married to her husband, Pampilo, since 1988. They have five children: the oldest is now 19 and is in college.

Virginia and her husband started farming two years after their marriage. Virginia can say that farming is not an easy job but she is still determined to succeed so she gives her best every day. She wants to earn more so that she can sustain her children’s education and the growing needs in her household.

Virginia joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She is now requesting a loan of Php 7,000 which she will use to buy farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Wennie

texts.en:
Wennie is a tenant on a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field and this is where she earns her income. She is 34 years old, married, and has children.

Wennie joined CEVI last year and shares that her loan was really helpful in her business. She is now requesting PHP 7,000 which she will use to purchase farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Roque

texts.en: Roque farms for a living. He plants rice crops to earn an income for his family. He got married to his wife Chona in 2003 and they now have a one-year old child. He wants to start saving now for his child’s future education. He also wants to improve his family’s living condition. Roque needs additional capital for his farm. He applied for a loan worth 7,000 Philippine pesos. If granted, he will use the loan to buy farm supplies needed at his farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina D. C. is a 36-year-old, hardworking mother who loves her three children. Her husband, Diosdado, is 40 years old and is a driver.

To help to sustain her family, Edwina started a business providing manicure and pedicure services and also food vending. She is applying for a new loan of Php 10,000 to buy a manicure set and the remaining money will be used for her food-vending business. 

In the future, Edwina hopes to establish her own canteen (outdoor cafe) where she can give better service to her regular customers. She also wants to be able to save for her children's education and to have a comfortable house to live in and a happy family to live with.

loans.use: To buy a manicure set and to use for her food vending business

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena Z. is 19 years old and is the mother of a 10-month old child. She is a new mother and wishes that her baby will have a very good life when she grows up.

Rowena is also a farmer and is tilling a small rice field. The income she makes from the farm really helps her family to buy food, clothing and other basic needs.

Rowena would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm supplies

loans.name: Lydie Kanon

texts.fr: Née en 1960 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, A. Lydie Kanon vit depuis 22 ans environs au quartier Houinmè, dans le quatrième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Mariée à GANBIA Waliou un chauffeur, Lydie Kanon est mère de quatre enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Lydie Kanon vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Houinmè. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. N'ayant jamais fréquenté l'école, Lydie Kanon vend de la nourriture (riz accompagné de sauce) à son domicile. Lydie Kanon s'approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo. Lydie Kanon a 10 ans d'expérience dans cette activité et a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. La clientèle de Lydie Kanon s’accroît au jour le jour ; mais Lydie Kanon n’arrive pas à la satisfaire parce que les moyens financiers dont elle dispose actuellement sont faibles. C’est la raison pour laquelle Lydie Kanon sollicite un troisième crédit pour renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Born in 1960 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, Ms. A. Lydie Kanon has been living for about 22 years in the Houinmè quarter, in the 4th district of the city of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Married to Mr. GANBIA Waliou, a driver, she is the mother of four children, some of whom are in school. She lives together with her children and husband in Houinmè. The couple jointly ensures that family expenses are covered. Never having attended school, Lydie Kanon sells food (rice served with sauce) out of her home. She stocks up at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. She has ten years of experience in this business and has already obtained two ALIDé loans, which she has repaid. Her customer base is growing day by day. But she isn't managing to satisfy them because the funds at her disposal are currently low. For these reasons, Lydie Kanon is requesting a third loan for bolstering her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of rice and sauce condiments (tomaotes, chili peppers, onions, etc.)

loans.name: Jogilyn

texts.en:
Jogilyn C. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 21 years old and is married.

Jogilyn owns and operates a business providing "habal-habal" services to local community members (a habal-habal is a motorcycle with an extended seat that carries 2-6 passengers), her husband serve as the driver of their motor vehicle. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jogilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI.

Jogilyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 


About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary A. O. is thirty-eight years old, widowed, and has three children who are all in school. Her business is located at Kondele in Kisumu, a lakeside city in Kenya. Her business is situated along the Kondele-Kibos road within a residential area and it is well known by the name of Maroon Enterprise.

Rosemary is involved in selling timber and poles to individual developers in Kisumu and institutions as well. She also has a hardware store where she sells nails and timber, and she provides transport services. Her major challenge is theft of timber from the yard and police harrassment due to illegal logging. She is using her loan to add to her stock of timber. In future, she hopes to grow her business and open a carpentry shop at the timber yard. She is very hard-working, reliable, polite, and jovial.

loans.use: Timber

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to make her business larger

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is a 48-year-old woman who is married and blessed with seven children. She and her husband work together to raised their big family. They are currently living at Taghangin, Morong, Rizal, Philippines. Josephine is a woman with good faith to defeat all challenges to reach her dreams.

In 2004, Josephine joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines. As a member of ASHI for almost six years, she has shown very good performance in her attendance at center meetings and weekly repayments. Her business still exists and, therefore, she is qualified to acquire larger loans.

Josephine runs a variety store. She started her store through her initiative in dealing with customers. She wants to continue her business as it gives her a good income to support the educational needs of her children. She is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 to use as additional capital to improve her business and her income.

Josephine dreams of growing her variety store into a mini-grocery store and expanding it to other villages. Her seven children are her inspiration to pursue her variety store.

Josephine now feels very happy with the services of ASHI and Kiva. It gives her a big chance to pursue her family dreams. She hopes that ASHI and Kiva continue the service for a long time and help many families who want to get ahead.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her general store

loans.name: Djumanazar

texts.ru: Бобомуратов Джуманазар проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 51 год. Женат, имеет 10 детей. Бобомуратов Джуманазар в своей мастерской работает более 10 лет. Он занимается ремонтом электроники. Кредит берет для закупа запастных частей аппаратуры, чтобы предоставит качественную услугу.
texts.en:
Djumanazar B. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 51 years old, married and has 10 children. Djumanazar has been working at his repair shop for over 10 years. He repairs electronics. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of equipment spare parts, in order to provide quality service.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of equipment spare parts

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael O. R. is 48 years old, married and has six children between the ages of ten and one years old. He owns a garage and sells auto spare parts on a busy street in Kisumu. He employs three people. He has been in this kind of business for the last 19 years. 

Since his business is doing well, he made a decision to take out a loan to buy more auto spare parts to expand his business. He works hard from early morning to late evening to make sure that he is not thrown out of business as there are so many people doing the same kind of business as his. He hopes to buy a car some day. He is a very hardworking and determined man.

loans.use: Auto spares

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy is a 27-year-old single man. He has been running stationary and printing services in Nairobi for three years. His business is named Lisma Enterprises and he has one employee. Most of his customers are advocates, churches and advertising companies. He also offers cleaning services for extra income.

Kennedy has requested a loan of Kes 80,000 through Faulu Kenya. He intends to add stock such as business items and a machine for his business. He hopes to grow his business into a multi-billion-dollar business.

Kennedy describes himself as focused and he believes nothing is impossible in life.

loans.use: To add stock and buy a machine for his business

loans.name: Celia's Group

texts.en: Celia B. is from the village of Cabisera 9-11, San Anton, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Celia is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Celia B.'s Group. Celia is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Celia operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling personal products, such as lotion and perfumes, in the local community. Celia has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. Celia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celia has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Celia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Celia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Solange

texts.en:
Solange is 30 years old and is married with two children aged 7 and 9. Her family lives in Kayonza, a region of Rwamagana located in the Eastern Province of Rwanda, approximately an hour-and-a-half drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Solange has been in the business of working as a retailer in her shop for the past two years. She really appreciates her business and she opens her shop from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Solange has been a hardworking businesswoman in her business and therefore she is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing some additional goods for sale. These additional goods include soft drinks and some other beverages.

Solange is expecting to earn more profits that will help her take good care of her family as well as enable her to save a portion of them. She is thankful to all Kiva lenders that are ready to contribute to the success of her business.

loans.use: To buy additional goods like juice and some other beverages

loans.name: Jamuna

texts.en:
Mrs. Jamuna T. is a shopkeeper in the town of Chetrapati, Kathmandu. She opened her grocery store six years ago as a way to strengthen the economic condition of her family. She sells different types of items, including rice, maize and snacks.

Competition is tougher than it used to be because there are now lots of grocery stores near hers. To stay in business, Mrs. Jamuna needs to sell goods cheaply, and that means investing money in her store. That is why she is requesting a loan to improve her store.

Mrs. Jamuna is married and has three children, all of whom are still in school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Bhagbati

texts.en:
Bhagbati S. lives in Chetrapati, Kathmandu. Chetrapati is one of the busiest cities of Kathmandu and most of the people in this region are engaged in small business. Mrs. Bhagbati Shresth lives with her mother-in-law, husband, one son and one daughter. Her husband, Mr. Prachandra Bahadhur S., works in a government office. Both her son and daughter are studying as well as working.

Mrs. Bhagbati S. opened her photo studio and watch shop more than five years ago. She employs two workers in her shop where she sells different brands of watches. She opened her shop to upgrade the living standard of her family. In addition, she wants to be independent and she doesn’t like to ask for money from her husband.

Now, Mrs. Bhagbati S. is requesting an Rs 20,000 loan to buy different varieties and brands of watches.

loans.use: To buy more watches for her store

loans.name: Solange

texts.en:
Solange is 30 years old and is married with two children aged 7 and 9. Her family lives in Kayonza, a region of Rwamagana located in the Eastern Province of Rwanda, approximately an hour-and-a-half drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Solange has been in the business of working as a retailer in her shop for the past two years. She really appreciates her business and she opens her shop from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Solange has been a hardworking businesswoman in her business and therefore she is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing some additional goods for sale. These additional goods include soft drinks and some other beverages.

Solange is expecting to earn more profits that will help her take good care of her family as well as enable her to save a portion of them. She is thankful to all Kiva lenders that are ready to contribute to the success of her business.

loans.use: To buy additional goods including soft drinks and some other beverages

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua O. A. is 27 years old, married and has two children who are in school. His business is located at Oile market, off the highway in Kisumu. He sells secondhand books to college students, high school pupils and parents of primary school-going children.

Joshua has been in this business for the last six years and says that his major challenges are inadequate capital, harassment by the local government, and too many people doing the sA. thing as him so customers are spoilt by the choice. However, he is determined to expand his business by opening a bookshop, attracting a larger market and becoming the major bookseller in Kisumu. He is using his loan to buy more books, especially for the pupils who are starting high school. He is a very hardworking and honest man.

loans.use: To buy books

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Mrs. Rita B. is a 41-year-old married woman with a daughter and son. They live in Bhatkepati, Lalitpur. Her husband, Mr. Shyam Krishna Bashnet, is a driver. Both her son and daughter took the SLC (School Leaving Certificate) exam this year.

Mrs. B. started selling milk three years ago. She already owns one cow. She's requesting a loan of 30000.00 Nepalese rupees to buy another young cow to sell milk in the local area. Since they live in a growing neighborhood, she believes that there will be an increase in demand for milk. Nepalese people love to drink cow's milk, so demand for milk is increasing constantly. 

She wishes to spend her income on her children's education.

loans.use: To buy another cow

loans.name: Elenita's Group

texts.en: Elenita L.'s main source of income comes from selling fruits and vegetables in her community. She is 51 years old, married and has three adult children. She is from the village of Burgos, Naguilian, Isabela. Elenita has been in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Elenita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elenita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. Elenita is the leader of a 7 member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Elenita L. Group". About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Falilath

texts.fr: A. Falilath est née en 1972 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a une dizaine d'année que Falilath s'est installée au quartier Foun-Foun, dans le quatrième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à YAYA Mourana un transitaire, Falilath est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. C'est avec ses enfants et son mari qu'elle vit. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour subvenir à ses différents besoins et venir en aide à son mari, Falilath vend de la nourriture (riz accompagné de sauce, bouillie de maïs) et aussi divers produits à Porto-Novo. C'est à Cotonou et à Ikpinlé, un marché de vente de produits vivriers, que Falilath s'approvisionne. Falilath avait bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Falilath ambitionne accroître la taille de son activité et mieux faire face à la demande de ses clients. Mais compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose, Falilath sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Falilath was born in 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Ten years ago, she got situated in the Foun-Foun quarter, in the 4th district of the city of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Married to YAYA Mouran, a shipping agent, she is the mother of three children who are all in school. She lives with her three children and husband. Together, the couple ensures that family expenses are covered. To meet her different needs and to help out her husband, Falilath sells food (rice served with sauce; and cornmeal porridge) and also a variety of goods, in Porto-Novo. She stocks up in Cotonou and at Ikpinlé, a market for staple foods. Falilath had benefited from two ALIDé loans, which she has repaid. Her ambition is to increase the size of her business and to cope better with the demands of her customers. But given the few financial means at her disposal, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn and rice;and sauce condiments

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Né le 16 Juin 1976 à Sikasso, Monsieur  Adama Berthé est marié et réside avec son épouse et leurs trois enfanfs à Banconi, un des quartiers péripheriques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Berthé, après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié aux activités de commerce notamment à l’achat et la vente des volailles il y a environ huit  ans. Il dispose d’une une place au niveau du marché à volailles de Wayerma I. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses volailles. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
 Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter, 30 poulets, 20 pintades, 10 paires de dindons, 5 paires de canards, 4 paires de oies. 
Il achete ses volailles dans les villages environnants de la ville de Sikasso et effectue sa vente en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle diverse et variée.
 Avec ce prêt il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement  pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on June 16, 1976 in Sikasso, Mr. Adama Berthé is married and resides with his wife and their three children in Banconi, one of the suburbs of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having worked in several jobs unsuccessfully, he got introduced about eight years ago to commercial work, especially in the buying and selling of poultry. He has a spot at the poultry market of Wayerma I and is in high demand by his customers for the quality of his poultry. To satisfy his burgeoning customer base, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his first individual loan. With this first loan, he intends to buy: 20 chickens, 20 Guinea hens, 10 pairs of turkeys, 5 pairs of ducks, and 4 geese. He buys his poultry from the villages surrounding Sikasso city, and he sells at the retail level, accepting cash or credit from a diverse and varied customer base. With this loan, he envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will essentially be used to cover the loan interest and to invest the rest into his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying poultry

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza M. is a new ASHI member. She is woman full of determination to rise above poverty. She is married and the mother of three minor children. She lives in Antipolo, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

She decided to join Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, hoping to access capital for her sari-sari store (general store). Now she is requesting a loan of 5,000 pesos to pay for 15 sacks of charcoal, cases of soft drinks and many other groceries for the store.

With the opportunity given to her by ASHI and Kiva, she believes that she is getting nearer to the fulfillment of her dreams.

loans.use: Pay for 15 sacks of charcoal, cases of soft drinks and many other groceries for the store

loans.name: Radjabali

texts.ru: Одинамадов Раджабали проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 69 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Одинамадов Раджабали растениеводством занимается более 15 лет. В своем саду сажает деревья. Кредит берет для посева урожая.
texts.en:
Radjabali O. lives in the Hamadoni district. He is 69 years old, married and has 3 children. Radjabali has been involved in horticulture for over 15 years. He plants trees in his garden. He is requesting this loan for the new planting.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: New planting

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kadiatou

texts.fr:
Kadiatou B. est née le 07 Mai 1966 à BanamB. ( une des préfectures de la région de Koulikoro). Elle est divorcée et mère de 4 enfants en sa charge. Elle réside avec ses enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Kaboïla II, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Kadiatou B., après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée finalement à  l’activité de restauration depuis plus de quinze ans. Elle mène son activité  à Kaboïla II en face de l’antenne de Soro Yiriwaso de Sikasso, tous les jours. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses repas. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel .
Elle compte acheter avec ce deuxième prêt, des viandes de brousses avec les chasseurs des localités environnantes de Sikasso, 40kg de poissons frais, 40kg de haricot, 25 poulets, 1 sac de pomme de terre, 30 kg de haricot vert et des condiments alimentaires.
 Les plats alimentaires sont vendus au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée des femmes, des jeunes (célibataires) surtout de noctambules. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Kadiatou B. was born on 7th May 1966 at BanamB. (one of the "prefectures" in the region of Koulikoro). She is divorced and has four children in her care. She lives with her children in a large and extended traditional family in Kaboïla II, a town in the centre of Sikasso (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having had many unsuccessful business ventures, Kadiatou B. finally entered into the restauration business over 15 years ago. She carries out her business in Kaboïla II every day opposite the Sikasso agency of Soro Yirwaso. She is in great demand from her customers owing to the quality of her meals. In order to satisfy the ever increasing number of customers, she decided to join the micro-finance company, Soro Yiriwaso, where she is on her second individual loan. With this second loan she is planning on buying bushmeat ("viande de brousse") from hunters in the areas surrounding Sikasso, 40kg of fresh fish, 40kg of beans, 25 chickens, one bag of potatoes, 30 kg of grean beans and some condiments. The meals are sold for cash or credit to a customer base made up of women, young single people, above all night-owls. She aims to make a monthly profit of 100,000FCFA which will be used principally to increase her working capital, contribute to household expenses and pay interest on her loan.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for restauration business

loans.name: Sandhya

texts.en:
Mrs. Sandhya K. is a resident of Bhakepati in the Kathmandu district. Bhakepati is one of the developing villages of Kathmandu and most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural farming.

Mrs. Sandhya lives in a single family with her husband and two children. She has one son and one daughter. Her daughter is studying in grade 10 and her son is studying in grade 9.

Both Mrs. Sandhya and her husband, Mr. Dipak K., are engaged in their own flower garden. They grow different types of food in their garden. They sell their flowers in the local market. Now Mrs. Sandhya is requesting a 15000.00 Nepalese rupee loan to buy different types of seeds and fertilizers for their work.

loans.use: To buys seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Gloriose

texts.en:
Gloriose is 26 years old and is married with three children with ages 1, 3 and 6. She and her family live Gakenke, in the Northern Province of Rwanda. There, Gloriose owns a shop selling a variety of goods such as toothpaste, soap, and many other cosmetics products.

Apart from selling cosmetics products, Gloriose also sells some drinks. The hours of her business are from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day and this is her seventh successful year in this business.

Gloriose is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of adding some cosmetics goods and drinks to her business. With this additional merchandise, she hopes to earn more profits which in turn will allow her to save for the future of her family as well as keep her business stable.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods including cosmetics and drinks

loans.name: Khatera Shabana Group

texts.en:
Pari Gull is the group leader of Khatera Shabana Group. There are three members in this group and they each want to expand and progress their business. They have requested a group loan 30,000 Afghani.

Pari Gull is 45 years old and has four children, all going to school. She wants to takes a loan for her husband’s business of selling towels. He buys towels from the bazaar at low prices and sells them in the market near his house.

Khatera wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of selling cosmetics. He would like to expand his business and wants to buy the necessary materials.

Shabana wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of selling shoes. He needs this loan for his business because he wants to progress his shop and change it to a large store and desires more clients in his store.

They thank all lenders of Kiva and AFSG in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy necessary materials for her husband's business

loans.name: Rodolfo's Group

texts.en: Rodolfo V. is from the village of Centro Sur, Alcala, Cagayan. He is 58 years old and is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Rodolfo is married and has three adult children. He owns and operates a transportation business, providing motorcycle transport services to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Rodolfo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for the repair and maintenance of the motorcycle used in his business. This loan will be his first from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to financially support immediate members of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair and maintain the motorcycle used in his business

loans.name: Suntali

texts.en: Mrs. Suntali K. (see this note on Nepali names) is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Bhatkepati. She sells a variety of grocery items in her shop and uses her earnings to fulfill the daily needs of her family and to support her children’s education. Several years ago, Mrs. Suntali K.’s husband died and therefore she is solely responsible for raising her four children. Her two sons and two daughters are studying in higher secondary school. All of her children also help her with the shop. Mrs. Suntali K. is requesting an Rs 20,000 loan to buy grocery items such as rice and maize for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana S. lives in Ijevan city with her family: her husband, son and daughter. Her son is a policeman, her daughter is jobless and her husband is a joiner.

About 30 years ago, Svetlana worked as a teacher in Ijevan School. Now she is retired and, since 2001, has operated a wooden shop where she manages her food and mixed product trading.

A few months ago, Svetlana start to build a new shop near her house. For speedy completion of the shop construction, Svetlana asks for a 900,000 AMD loan.

In the photo you can see Svetlana with her grandson and granddaughter.

loans.use: To pay for speedy completion of her shop construction

loans.name: Joanes

texts.en:
Joanes A. O. is thirty one years old, is married and has three children. His business is located at Oile market, a busy market with many people doing the same business as him. Oile is in Kisumu city where the inhabitants are the Luo people.

Joanes has been operating his business of selling secondhand books for the last six years. He sells his books to college students, high school pupils, and parents of school-going children. His major challenges are inadequate capital, harassment by the local government and, of course, so many other people doing the same business as him.

Joanes is using the loan to buy a stock of books and he dreams of having a bookshop in town and hopes to be the leading book seller in Kisumu town. He is a hardworking and honest go-getter.

loans.use: To buy more books to sell

loans.name: Ernalyn

texts.en:
Ernalyn G. is a new member of ASHI. She is married to Danny, 24 years old and a carpenter. She and her husband are blessed with two children.. One child is three years old and the other is two years old . Despite many challenges in her life, she never gave up fighting against poverty.


Her sewing business has grown and requires more capital to sustain her business. She joined ASHI to secure additional capital amounting to PHP 5,000 for her sewing business. She also wants to start selling rice. Because of this, She requests a loan through ASHI so that she can support the growth of her business and be able to meet the growing demands of her customers.


Without capital Ernalyn business will not grow and she will not be able to give satisfactory service to her customer. Through the support of ASHI and KIVA, She hopes to see herself and her family that someday change their standard of living and away from ties of poverty.

loans.use: Additional capital for sewing business and rice retail

loans.name: Zuhra

texts.en:
G. Zuhra is 60 years old. She is a kindergarten teacher. However, for 17 years Zuhra has been selling clothing. She sells socks for men and children in the central local market. Zuhra spends the income from the business for the well being of her family. Today she requests 5,000 Somoni to purchase new goods to sell. Zuhra promises to pay the loan on time and thanks all for supporting her.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new goods to sell

loans.name: Sarita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarita D. is a tailor in the village of Thecho. She makes different types of ladies dresses which are very famous among Nepali women, like kurta-sulwal, blouses, etc. Before starting her own shop, she took six months of training for tailoring work. Sarita D. uses her income to help her husband with fulfilling household expenses.

Sarita D. is requesting a 20000.00 Nepalese rupee loan to buy raw materials for her tailoring work.

Mrs. Sarita D. lives in a single family with her husband and one son. Her husband, Mr. Rajiv D., is a driver and her son is studying in primary school.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her tailoring work

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 31 years old and married with two children, one of whom is in school. For two years, she has been running a hotel business (in Africa, a "hotel" is often a primitive restaurant) where she has employed four people. She previously owned a shop but currently relies partially on her husband’s salary.  

She appreciates Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner, for training her on business record-keeping and customer service. She requested 60,000 Kenyan shillings so as to purchase more groceries to add to her stock and for renovation of the business premises. She hopes to grow her hotel into a restaurant and also construct rooms for accommodation in future. She describes herself as hardworking and visionary.

loans.use: Add stock of groceries

loans.name: Khursandmurod

texts.en:
M. Khursandmurod is a hard-working man who actively contributes to the well-being of his family by selling vegetable oil in the market. He is married with three children. Khursandmurod spends many hours at his small stand in the market, waiting on his customers. In traditional Tajik cuisine, the majority of the dishes are fried or cooked using cottonseed oil. Especially our national dish “Pilau” needs a lot of cottonseed oil in order for it to be delicious. So the goods that Khursandmurod sells are of popular demand among the population.

Khursandmurod realizes that with the excellent quality and customer service he gives, he can grow his business. Today Khursandmurod is planning to increase his business. For this reason he requests 4600 Somoni. Khursandmurod is counting on your help and thanks you for your support.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cottonseed oil ito add to his inventory

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 29 years old, married with four children, aged between 2 and 10 years. Beatrice lives in Burera, a region of Ruhengeri, in the northern province of Rwanda. From here to Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda, it takes two hours' drive. Beatrice has been in the business of selling tea in her small restaurant for the past 4 years. The business’s working hours are from 6 AM until late in the evening every day except Sunday.

Beatrice is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her business through purchasing more kilos of sugar and some equipment as the number of her customers keep increasing. With these additional business inputs, Beatrice hopes to earn more profits and she will use some of those profits to reinvest in her business as well as for supporting her extended family and loved ones.

loans.use: Additional equipment and some beverages for sale

loans.name: Gyan Kumari

texts.en: Mrs. Gyan Kuamri M. is a farmer in the village of Thecho. She owns a piece of land where she grows different types of green vegetables. She prefers to grow seasonal vegetables on her land. She sells her vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening. Now she is requesting Rs 15,000 as a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for her agricultural work.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Deepa

texts.en:
Mrs. Deepa M., a resident of Thecho, lives in a nuclear family with her husband and one son. Her husband's name is Mr. Radhay Shyam M. and he works with a printing press. Her son is now studying in pre-primary school. Mrs. Deepa opened her cosmetic shop four years ago to help her husband raise their living standards. She sells different varieties of cosmetic goods in her shop, such as face-wash, creams, glass bangles, etc.

Now Mrs. Deepa is requesting Rs 20,000 as a loan to buy various types of cosmetic goods for her shop. Mrs. Deepa wants to save her income to provide better education for her child.

loans.use: to buy cosmetic goods for her inventory

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en:
P. Muhabbat is 54 years old. She is widow and has one child. After the death of her husband, she had to find a way to earn money and decided to start her own business. Muhabbat is selling children’s clothing at the local market of Dushanbe city. She is trying to have wide range of goods so as to be able to meet the requirements of her customers and to satisfy the needs of the customers with different levels of income.

Today Muhabbat requests 4000 Somoni with the purpose of purchasing additional merchandise to increase the range of her goods. Be an important part of the growth of Muhabbat’s business!

loans.use: Purchasing clothing to add to her inventory

loans.name: Jelyn

texts.en:
Jelyn S. is a 24-year-old and a mother who cares for her three children. She is married to Mario, who is a laborer. All of their three children are of minor age. To assist her husband to support the family, Jelyn started a business buying and selling frozen foods.

She has applied for a first loan to buy an assortment of frozen products for her business. She has joined ASHI to secure capital for frozen foods and expand her business.

As a new ASHI member, she hopes to be able to send her children to school until they finish college. She also dreams of building a durable house of their own. With the chance given to her family by ASHI, KIVA's partner, the couple believes that they are getting closer to achieving their family dreams.

loans.use: purchase of frozen food products to expand her business

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.en:
Gulbahor is a hard-working entrepreneur from Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan. She and her husband have two children. She runs a business where she sells kids' clothing and women's underwear.

Gulbahor started her business 10 years ago and has run it with extreme care and seriousness. It is an important source of income for her family of four, considering that her husband does not earn enough money to support the family. Gulbahor has requested a loan of 5000 Somoni so that she can purchase additional inventory of winter clothing for kids and to continue developing her business. Thanks to this loan, she will be able to grow her business further and help feed her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing winter clothing for kids

loans.name: Geneviève

texts.fr: Née en 1960 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, D. Geneviève vit depuis 19 ans à Djassin, dans le troisième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. C'est une veuve et mère de six enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Mais trois seulement sont encore à sa charge. Geneviève vit seule avec ses trois enfants et assure seule les charges de la famille. Geneviève n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Geneviève vend de la nourriture (pâte de maïs accompagnée de différentes sauces)à son domicile. Geneviève s'approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo et aussi à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Geneviève exerce cette activité depuis 5 ans et a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. Geneviève voudrait renforcer son fonds de roulement et augmenter la quantité de repas préparé par jour, ce qui lui permettra d'agrandir sa clientèle et d'augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. N'ayant pas suffisamment de moyens financiers pour y arriver, Geneviève sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1960 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, Ms. D. Geneviève has lived for nineteen years in Djassin, in the 3rd district of the city of Porto-Novo. She is a widow and the mother of six children, who are all in school. But only three of them are still in her care. She lives alone with her children, and by herself she ensures that family expenses are covered. Geneviève has never been to school. To meet the needs of her children, she sells food (cornmeal mash served with different sauces) out of her home. She stocks up at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo and also in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been in this business for five years and has already benefited from two ALIDé loans, which she has repaid. Geneviève would like to boost her working capital and to increase the quantity of meals made each day. This will enable her to expand her customer base and to increase her sales. Lacking sufficient financial means to do so, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn and some sauce condiments (tomatoes, onions, chili peppers)

loans.name: Nakali

texts.en:
Mrs. Nakali D. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Chapagaun. She opened her grocery four years ago to uplift the economic conditions of her family. She sells different types of grocery goods such as rice, maize, snacks, noodles, etc. in her shop. Now she is requesting a loan of Rs 25,000 to buy different types of new grocery goods for her shop.

Mrs. D. lives with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Chandra Ram D., is a driver. She has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying at university and her daughter is studying in grade 9.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods for resale

loans.name: Marie Grace

texts.en:
Marie Grace I., 35, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Aniel I., a seaman, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn enough so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing their ‘buy and sell’ business for five years already.

Marie Grace has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than seven years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow five times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy different appliances and resell them on an installment basis. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 10,500 per month.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 15,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy additional home appliances for her 'buy and sell' business.

She hopes that her business will continue to provide them with enough income for her family’s everyday expenses.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying additional home appliances to resell

loans.name: Bahriniso

texts.en:
S. Bahriniso is 53 years old. She is married with 6 children. Bahriniso has been selling sportswear for men and boys for the past 15 years. She started because she had been out of work for some time and her children needed things which she couldn’t afford on her husband’s small income. With her savings she started to buy sportswear from her customers wholesale and has been selling it in the local market. Little by little she increased the number of clients and in that way, she has been supporting her children. 

Nevertheless, presently the selection of her inventory is poor and therefore she is requesting a loan of 4,800 Somoni. With this loan Bahriniso can purchase new and varied merchandise to offer her customers. With your support she will be able to increase her business and save money for her children’s expenses.

loans.use: Purchasing sportswear for men and boys

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
Consuelo H., 50, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Melchor H., a food vendor, she is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. Both of them have been in the food vending business for 22 years.

Consuelo has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than eight years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow 16 times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy ingredients for their food vending business. Her business lets her earn a profit of 15,500 per month.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 11,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business, buying rice, spaghetti and other ingredients for cooked meals.

She dreams that they will have a permanent place of business someday so that she can earn more for her family.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying rice, spaghetti and other ingredients for cooked meals

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.en:
B. Gulsara is 49 years old. She and her husband have raised 5 children. For 15 years already, Gulsara has been working in the local market of the city. She sells rice, green grams, buckwheat, and peas. These legumes are very popular in Tajikistan. They can be cooked in soups and as cereals; all are very nourishing, healthy, and tasty.

The business is very stable and generates the main income for the family as Gulsara's husband is currently unemployed. Today she requests 700 US Dollars as a loan to be used to increase her inventory by purchasing rice, green grams, buckwheat, and peas to sell. Gulsara thanks all for their support and promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing green grams, buckwheat, and peas for her inventory

loans.name: Gulmurod

texts.en:
B. Gulmurod is 41 years old, has a secondary school education, is married, and has 4 children. Gulmurod has been farming for 6 years. He learned this occupation from his father. He has land where he plants wheat, onions, and potatoes. Gulmurod will use his loan to fertilize his land and to purchase seeds for planting. After harvest, local residents will be able to purchase wheat, onions, and potatoes at a lower price than they would pay at the market. At the day of our visit Gulmurod was gone to the market and instead his wife and daughter were pictured. Gulmurod will pay back the loan on time and he thanks everyone supporting him. The well-being of this family is in your hands.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing fuel and lubricants, seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida B., 40, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Emilio B., a coconut vendor, she is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. Both of them have been selling coconuts as their business for seven years.

Nida has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow 12 times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy more coconuts from wholesalers. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 5,600 per month.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 17,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business, allowing her to buy more coconuts, seasoning and sugar.

She dreams that her business will eventually make her a coconut wholesaler someday so that they can earn more for their family.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more coconuts, seasoning and sugar

loans.name: Dhan Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Dhan Maiya D. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Chapagaun. She opened her grocery store two years ago to improve the economic conditions of her family. She sells different types of grocery goods such as rice, maize, different types of snacks, etc. in her shop. Now she is requesting RS 15,000 as a loan to buy grocery goods for her shop.

Mrs. D. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two sons. Her husband, Mr. Nanda Lal D., is a driver. Her older son is studying in grade 9 and her younger son is studying in grade 6.

loans.use: to buy grocery goods for her shop

loans.name: Mahmadsolih

texts.en:
D. Mahmadsolih is married and the father of four children. He works as a farmer everyday. Educated until secondary school, he had to quit early because he couldn't afford to attend. Bestowed with a good work ethic, Mahmadsolih has wholeheartedly committed himself to agriculture. Thanks to his hard work, he has today become a man known for his determination and serves as an example and reference for other farmers. He is growing vegetables: potato, onion, carrot and others. Mahmadsolih is now seeking a loan of $3,000 US to buy seeds, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants for his crops in the hopes of being well prepared for the upcoming season and to produce a good harvest at the end of the season. He can then better meet the needs of his family and improve his work conditions.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, mineral fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Champa

texts.en:
Mrs. Champa S. is a resident of Chapagaun, which is located in the Lalitpur district. Chapagaun is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur and most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural farming.

Mrs. Champa S. lives in a single family with her husband and three sons. Her husband and two older sons are drivers and her younger son is now studying.

Mrs. S. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Chapagaun. She opened her grocery store more than five years ago to uplift the economic condition of her family. Now she is requesting a 30000.00 Nepal rupees loan to buy different types of grocery goods for her business.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Zebiniso

texts.en: Zebiniso G. is 34 years old. She is married and the loving mother of three wonderful kids. Her husband is an entrepreneur and doesn't earn enough for the family consumption, that is why Zebiniso has been running grocery store for the past three years. She sells fruits, sweets, preserved food, juices, soft drinks and many other items in her grocery. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Zebiniso is respectful and patient with all of her customers, which attracts people and brings them back to her vending facility to buy groceries again. Zebiniso is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of $3,000 to increase the inventory she has for sale. One of her dreams is that her children progress by means of their studies. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Zebiniso reach all of her aspirations. loans.use: Buy foodstuffs to increase stock

loans.name: Ulukberdi

texts.en:
J. Ulukberdi is 58 years old. He is married and the father of 4 children. Ulukberdi is a hard-working and enterprising man who constantly tries to improve and do things better every day. He works hard in his fields where he spends as much time as possible providing the necessary care, fertilizing his land and spraying to prevent diseases and improve his yields. Ulukberdi needs tools and fertilizers to continue his difficult work, tending his crops so that they can be taken to the capital for sale. He is applying for a loan of 4000 Somoni. Let's be the ones who reach out our hands to help Ulukberdi!
