You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Oldemar U. F. is 22 years old and single. He lives with his parents and six siblings. He is requesting the loan to raise laying hens and chickens. He also wishes to construct a chicken coop and other arrangements on the farm. With this investment, he hopes to grow his business and be able to increase his income so he can improve his economic situation. This is the first time Oldemar has been financed by Kiva partner FUDECOSUR, and he tells us that the credit committee has greatly helped him and provided him many facilities when applying for the loan. He hopes that this project will strengthen his business and increase his sales, thus offering his family a better quality of life and more economic stability. About FUDECOSUR: The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase laying hens and chickens

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entreprener is 33 years old and married. He attended primary school and passed the primary school exam. 

For more than three years, he has been operating a restaurant. The purpose of this loan is to develop his restaurant by purchasing rice, beans, okra, broad-bean-cabbages, and other food to attract more customers. He will also purchase huge pots, an oven and a grilling machine. He has a good reputation in the market because of the good quality of his food. He has many waiters to serve his customers. 

It is significant and worth mentioning that this loan is a renewal of a loan that he used to expand his restaurant. He made all payments on the original loan in a timely manner and is a worthy and trusted customer. With his original loan, he had the capacity to improve his restaurant significantly and to  decorate it in a nice and tidy style. 

He prepares the most delicious and flavorful foods. His food has turned customers into permanent clients. The cleanness and delicious food are two significant advantages of his restaurant.

loans.use: To buy food, huge pots, an oven, and a grilling machine.

loans.name: Francisco Geronimo

texts.es:
Francisco García de 55 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento solo cuenta con agua y luz como servicios básicos,  esta casado y tiene 3 hijos de 15, 13, 11 años de edad estudiantes de colegios fiscales.

Francisco empezó tomando fotos con una cámara prestada, poco a poco reunió dinero para comprar los químicos para hacer cloro y también implemento en su negocio la venta de carbón. 

Ahora el trabaja con su esposa todos los días desde las 07h00 hasta las 21h00, vendiendo por litro y galón el cloro, fundas de carbón, ya no toma foto porque no tiene cámara, hasta ahora no ha tenido complicaciones en su negocio.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar una cámara para retomar la actividad fotográfica, y también comprar químicos para hacer el cloro. En el futuro quiere una camioneta para transportar mejor su mercadería.
texts.en:
Francisco García is 55 years old and lives in the suburbs of Fortín de Guayaquil in a house made of cement that only has basic water and electrical services. He is married and has three children, ages 15, 13 and 11, who are in public school. Francisco started taking pictures with a borrowed camera, and little by little he raised money to purchase chemicals to make chlorine and also started a business selling charcoal. Now he and his wife work every day from 7 a.m.-9 p.m. selling chlorine by the liter and gallon and also cases of charcoal. He no longer takes pictures because he doesn't have a camera, and up until this point he has not had any complications with his business. With the loan he is requesting, he plans to purchase a camera so he can take up photography again, as well as purchase chemicals to make chlorine. In the future he wants a truck so he can better transport his merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a camera and chemicals to make chlorine

loans.name: Marvin

texts.es:
Marvin Z. L., tiene la edad de 34 años, es casado, y tiene 3 hijos, que son su mayor prioridad. Los hijos tienen 9,8, y un año respectivamente. El crédito lo quiere para la compra ganado para su finca.El desea aumentar el numero de animales para mejorar la calidad de las razas. Tiene una área de 2.5 hectáras de potrero para el desarrollo del ganado. No es la primera vez que don Marvin se financia con  FUDECOSUR, el manifiesta que el comité de crédito le ha ayudado mucho a que su proyecto crezca, además que está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron.
El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mejor estabilidad económica.

About FUDECOSUR:
The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Marvin Zuniga L. is 34, married, and has 3 children-they are his main priority. His children are 9, 8 and one year respectively. The loan he is asking for is to buy cattle for his ranch. He wishes to increase the number of animals to improve the quality in the breeding. He has 2.5 hectares of pasture for the development of the cattle. This is not the first time that Marvin has financed with FUDECOSUR. He tells us that the credit committee has helped him greatly with his expansion project, and he is very happy with the terms that he has been given. He hopes that in the future he can offer his family a better quality of life and greater economic stability. About FUDECOSUR: The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Neva Linette

texts.es:
Neva Linette R. C. es una señora de 43 años de edad la cual vive con su madre y sus dos hijos en una comunidad llamada Coquital localizada en Los Chiles, provincia de Alajuela; está comunidad se destaca por ser una zona montañosa y por estar muy cerca de la frontera norte de nuestro país. Sus principales actividades económicas son la ganadería y la agricultura específicamente se da la siembra de granos básicos y  naranja.

Actualmente doña Neva tiene un negocio propio, empezó hace poco con un salón de belleza pero comenta que le va muy bien. Con el mantiene a su familia y cubre los gastos de su hogar dice que ella brinda un muy buen servicio y atención a sus clientes.

Agrega que le llena de motivación y orgullo el hecho de tener su propio negocio y ofrecer a su comunidad un servicio necesario, tomando en consideración que es una comunidad que no es muy céntrica y por lo que muchos habitantes  se ven en la necesidad de desplazarse hacia otros lugares para obtener ese servicio. Asegura que trabaja con mucho esmero, dedicación y disciplina y así puede ver como su negocio día con día crece.  

Doña  Neva requiere un préstamo de ¢658.000 (seiscientos cincuenta y ocho mil colones) para comprar una secadora, una plancha para cabello, un “lava cabezas”, y productos varios. Además de diferentes materiales de construcción para agrandar su local.

Ella forma parte de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Rapicrédito Progreso Futuro Coquital, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este es el primer crédito de doña Neva y con el espera crecer mas personalmente y profesionalmente como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Neva Linette R. C. is 43 years old. She lives with her mother and her two children in a community called Coquital located in Los Chiles, Alajuela province. This community is in a mountainous region very close to the northern border of our country. The main economic activities are raising cattle and agriculture, specifically basic grains and oranges. Neva has her own business. She opened a beauty salon recently and says it is going well. With the salon she supports her family and covers her living costs. She says that she provides her clients with very good service. She says that it motivates her and makes her proud to have her own business and to offer her community a necessary service - considering that her community is not very centrally located and many residents have to travel to other locations for this type of service. She says that she works with great care, dedication, and discipline and therefore can see her business grow daily. Neva requires a loan of 658.000 Colones to purchase a drier, a hair iron, a hair washing sink, and various products. She also will purchase construction materials to expand her shop. She is part of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal Rapicrédito Progreso Futuro Coquital, one of the 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This is her first loan, and she hopes to grow personally and professionally as a micro-entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of equipment and materials

loans.name: Wilma

texts.es:
La Señora Wilma es una cliente responsable y dinamica esta casada y tiene un hijo  ella vive en el Barrio Monte Alto  y su esposo es el Sr. Benito, se dedica a trabajar de chofer, el esta afililiado en un sindicato de la ciudad, la Sra. Wilma tiene su negocio de venta de ropa, ella vende distintos tipos de ropa como pantalones y chompas que son los productos que mas venta tiene, ya tiene clientes que le hacen pedidos y directamente entrega.
 
El destino del crédito solicitado es para capital de trabajo comprar más mercadería por fin de año. 
La Sra. esta agradecido con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Wilma is a responsible and dynamic client. She is married and has a son. She lives in the Monte Alto neighborhood and her husband is Benito. He works as a driver and is affiliated with a union in the city. Wilma has a business selling clothing. She sells different types of clothing such as trousers and sweaters which are the most sold items. She has customers who make orders and who she delivers to directly. The requested loan is for working capital to purchase more merchandise for the end of the year. She is thankful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence provided by granting her the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase in working capital.

loans.name: Dios Es Nuestro Amparo Group

texts.en:
Maximlliano is the coordinator of the Dios es Nuestro Amparo (God is our shelter) group, and his story is representative of his group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients. His group is located in El Seybo, a rural town where the economy is based around agriculture and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable.  He makes his home in a simple structure with his wife and nine children.

Maximilliano is excited to be taking his fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid previous loans to grown his business. He plans to use this loan to purchase more blouses to sell.  He will use the profits to construct a concrete house for his family.  He thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Buy blouses to sell.

loans.name: Slmb Maroc Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at the S.L.M.B Maroc Primary School, Magburaka. S.L.M.B Primary school Maroc was built primarily for the purpose of Quranic reading, but later was transformed into English and Arabic learning. Presently, there are 20 teachers in the school and 705 pupils. S.L.M.B always makes good grades in public exams (The National Primary School Examinations-NPSE) and does well in sports. The school has produced a lot of highly qualified and trained professionals in all walks of life who are living and working in and outside of Sierra Leone.

This is the second loan S.L.M.B is accessing from Kiva through SMT. School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Fifty-seven-year-old Alimany K. (first row, second from right) is the head teacher at the school. He was born in Rochen, eight miles from Magburaka town. He is married with 9 children – 1 in college, 3 in secondary school and 5 in primary school. Alimany will use his loan to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: Pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Government Technical Institute Group

texts.en:
These gentlemen are staff members of the Government Technical Institute Magburaka, Tonkolili District, northern Sierra Leone. Government Technical Institute, Magburaka, was founded in 1962 by the government for the promotion of technical and vocational education. They teach mechanical engineering, carpentry and joinery, block laying and concreting, automobile engineering, plumbing and sheet metal work, painting and decoration and many more subjects. Presently, the institute has a total of 17 staff and 300 pupils.

Government Technical Institute Magburaka is the only government technical institute in Magburaka town. Over the years, the institution has been able to train many technicians serving both within and without Sierra Leone. It makes good grades at the external examinations organized by City and Guilds of London Institute. The institution also serves as a consultancy and guard to the people of Magburaka.

This is the second loan Government Technical Institute is requesting from Kiva through SMT. School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Santigie A. T. (first row, second from right) is a lecturer at the institute and head of this group. Santigie is 56 years old, married and has 3 children – 1 in Senior Secondary School and 2 already grown-ups and on their own. Santigie has been teaching for 10 years now. With his share of the loan, Santigie will pay school fees for his child and invest the rest in his farm. He will buy goats and sheep and palm seeds to plant in his palm-tree farm.

loans.use: Pay school fees for his child and invest the rest in agriculture

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy parts and material for engine repairs

loans.name: Suleyva

texts.es: La sra. Suleyva M. M. vende ropa usada ambulante en el municipio de san Rafael va a utilizar el financiamiento para comprar mas ropa variada y asi tener que ofrecerles a sus clientes, ella pasaba todo el dia haciendo los quehaceres de su casa porque la mama trabaja entonces pasaba aburrida y le dijo a la mama que le ayudara para poder ella tener su negocio y asi distraerse un poco vendiendo su mercadería, ella espera tener más ingreso ahora con este nuevo crédito por que así va a tener que ofrecerles a su clientela, Suleyva es casada no tiene hijo vive en la casa de su mama por que aun no han podido construir su casa, ya es el segundo crédito con nosotros y le han ayuda mucho.espera cada día trabajar más duro y que estos crédito le van a seguir ayudando para asi un dia cumplir sus sueños de poder tener su propia casa su esposo trabaja en la cementera como obrero
texts.en:
Senora Suleyva M. M. sells used clothing as a street vendor in the municipality of San Rafael. She will use this financing to buy additional pieces of clothing to offer to her clients. She used to spend all day doing the chores at her house because her mother works, then she got bored and her mother told her that she would help her to have her own business, so she could entertain herself selling her merchandise. With this new loan she hopes to have a greater income by offering a greater selection to her clientele. Suleyva is married without children. She lives in her mother's home because she has not yet been able to build her own house. This is the second loan through us, the loans are very helpful to her. Every day she hopes to work harder, and that these loans help her to get ahead so that one day she may fulfill her dream of having her own home. Her husband is a worker in the cement plant.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of used clothing

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.fr: Née en 1960 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, K. Rosalie vit depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Gbodjè dans le quatrième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Mariée à GLODJINOU Raphael, un enseignant, Rosalie est mère de six enfants dont trois sont à sa charge. Tous les enfants de Rosalie sont scolarisés. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Rosalie a très peu fréquenté. Pour satisfaire ses besoins, Rosalie mène comme activité, la vente de divers produits (huile d'arachide, savons, allumettes, farine de manioc, biscuits, etc.)à son domicile. Rosalie s'approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo. C'est depuis 6 ans que Rosalie mène cette activité, et a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Rosalie a bien remboursé les deux crédits dont elle a bénéficié. Rosalie voudrait renforcer son fonds de roulement et élever son activité, afin de mieux répondre à la demande de ses clients. Cependant, Rosalie ne dispose pas suffisamment de fonds pour y arriver. C'est la raison pour laquelle Rosalie sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1960 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, Rosalie K. has been living for the past ten years in the Gbodjè neighbourhood, part of the 4th district of Porto-Novo. Married to Raphael GLODJINOU, a teacher, Rosalie is the mother of six children, of which three are under her care. All the children have been to school. The couple share household expenses. Rosalie had very little education. To meet her needs, Rosalie sells various products from her home (peanut oil, soap, matches, cassava flour, cookies, etc.). She gets her supplies from the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. Rosalie has been in business for six months, and has already been granted two loans by ALIDé, both of which were fully reimbursed. Rosalie would like to increase her working capital and increase the level of her activity, to better respond to customer demand. She lacks the financial means to do so, which is why she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat d'huile d'arachide, biscuits, boîtes d'allumettes, savons et farine de manioc.Buy peanut oil, cookies, matchboxes, soap and cassava flour

loans.name: Emmanuel 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of her group, Emmanuel, and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural communities surrounding El Siebo, a rural town where agriculture dominates the economy and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their four children.

Maria is excited to be taking her 10th loan with Esperanza, a Kiva partner, after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business considerably. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by purchasing fruits as merchandise to sell. She will use the profits to reinvest in her business with the dream of one day owning her own store from which to sell fruitM. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Fruits to sell such as pineapple, passion fruit and oranges

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying used clothing

loans.name: Simeon

texts.es:
El Sr. Simeon vive en la localidad de Puerto Rico, comunidad de El Torno; es casado tiene 4 hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar, su actividad principal es el transporte de persona, en motocicleta, cuenta con su propia unidad de trabajo, su esposa trabaja como empleada domestica, con esta actividad ella ayuda en la economía de la familia. Ambos trabajan mucho para cumplir uno de sus sueños que es tener su casita propia y poder ver a sus hijos profesionales.

El destino del crédito es para la compra de una motocicleta, para poder incrementar sus ingresos y sacar adelante a su familia.

El Sr. Simeon es un persona responsable dinamica y trabajadora.

Esta muy agradecido con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Mr. Simeon lives in the Puerto Rico area, in El Tomo community. He is married with 4 school-aged children. His main job is transporting people on his motorcycle. He has one that he uses in the business. His wife works as a domestic servant and with this job she is able to help with the family expenses. They both work hard to be able to fulfill one of their dreams: to have their own little house, and to see their children become professionals. The loan will be used to buy a motorcycle to increase their income and to help the family get ahead. Mr. Simeon is dynamic, responsible and hard-working. He is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust offered him in granting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Conny Francis

texts.es: La Sra. Conny Francis E. Gutiérrez trabaja en la alcaldía municipal como asistente de bodega ella es lic. En administración de empresa, tiene cuatro años trabajando en esta institución, el crédito lo solicita para la construcción de su vivienda ya tenía los materiales de construcción solo necesitaba para el pago de la mano de obra para la construcción de su casa ya es el tercer crédito con ceprodel y todos los ha utilizado para construir su casita a ella le ha venido ayudar mucho ya que solo así va a poder cumplir sus sueños es casada no tiene hijos aun y espera que siempre ceprodel le ayude de esta manera otorgándole crédito ya que se siente muy agradecida con estos financiamientos.
texts.en:
Conny Francis E. Gutiérrez works in city hall as an assistant. She is licensed in business administration. She has four years experience working in this institution. The loan she's requesting is for the construction of her house. She already has the construction materials. She only needs it to pay for the labor of building her house. This is her third loan with Ceprodel and all of her loans have been used to build her little house. It has helped her a lot since she has been able to achieve her dreams only in this manner. She is married but does not have any children yet and she hopes that Ceprodel will always help her in this way granting her loans since she feels very thankful for this financing.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for the labor to build her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying mobile phone recharge cards

loans.name: Virginie

texts.fr: Née en 1954 à Kandi au Nord du Bénin, S. Virginie est mariée à KIKI Henri un gendarme à la retraite. Le couple a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Virginie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Djèrègbé Gbokpa sur la route de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Virginie vient en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les charges de la famille. Virginie a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire. Depuis près de 20 ans, Virginie mène comme activité, la vente de produits divers (savons, farine de manioc, piles, sucres, galettes d'arachide, bombons, etc.) à son domicile. Parallèlement à cette activité, Virginie vend également de l'huile d'arachide, ce qui lui permet d'avoir une autre source de revenus. C'est la première fois que Virginie sollicite de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit lui permettra d'agrandir son activité et d'augmenter sa clientèle et donc son chiffre d'affaire.
texts.en:
Born in 1954 in Kandi (North of Benin), Virginie S. is married to Henri KIKI, a retired policeman. The couple have three children, who are all in school. Virginie lives with her husband and children in Djèrègbé Gbokpa on the road to Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She assists her husband regarding household expenses, and interrupted her schooling at secondary level. For the past 20 years, Virginie has been selling a variety of products from her home (soap, cassava flour, batteries, sugar, peanut wafers, sweets, etc.). Additionally, she retails peanut oil, which gives her another source of income. This is the first time Virginie has requested a loan from ALIDé. It will allow her to expand her activities, increase her customer base, and consequently her turnover.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy peanut wafers, sugar, soap, cassava flour, and peanut oil

loans.name: Pedro Efrain

texts.es:
Pedro C. de 21 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín de Guayaquil, tiene solo en su casa como servicios básicos solo agua y luz, su esposa trabaja de guardia privado con ella tiene 1 hija de 4 meses. 

Pedro empezó hace 1 año atrás el negocio de la papelería, ya que le daba tiempo para estar con su esposa.

Ahora el trabaja con la ayuda de su esposa y su mama de las 06h30 hasta las 21h00 todos los días, el vende cuadernos, hojas, lapices y otros suministros de bazar, una de las complicaciones que tiene es que no tiene un local propio para la papelería.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar cuadernos, fomix, plumas, hojas entre otros suministros para agrandar el negocio. En el futuro quiere poner sucursales de su negocio.
texts.en:
Pedro C. is 21 years old. He lives in a suburban area in el Fortín de Guayaquil. In his home he only has basic services like water and light. His wife works as a private security guard. They have a 4 month old daughter. Pedro opened his stationery shop business one year ago, since it gave him time to be with his wife. Now he works with his wife and his mother from 6:30am until 9pm every day. He sells notebooks, loose leaf paper, pencils and other supplies in a market. One of the problems Pedro faces is that he does not have his own shop for the stationery business. With the loan he will purchase notebooks, foam molds, pens, and loose leaf paper among other supplies to grow his business. In the future he would like to have additional branches of his business.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Notebooks, pencils, paper

loans.name: G.s Jehova Es Mi Fortaleza Group

texts.es: El grupo Solidario Jehová Es Mi Fortaleza está conformado por Thelma y Josefa ambas se dedican a diferentes actividades económicas. Thelma se dedica a la una pulpería, hace mas de 9 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que ella es una persona muy alegre a pesar de tener 63 años de edad, la experiencia que su trabajo le ha enseñado ha sido la mejor pues es así que ha logrado darse cuenta lo que sus clientes solicitan el financiamiento es para la compra de capital de trabajo como golosinas, refrescos naturales, pan galletas entre otros productos y junto con su amiga deciden realizar estos financiamiento que son de gran ayuda. Josefa se dedica a la venta de tortillas hace mas de 9 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que es una mujer muy trabajadora. Ellas sueñan mantener este negocio, por lo que es muy importante para las dos.
texts.en:
The group Jehová Es Mi Fortaleza (Jehova is My Strength) is made up of Thelma and Josefa, who have different businesses. Thelma has had a general store for over 9 years, which is why she is so happy despite being 63 years old. The best experience that her work has provided her is that she has realized what her customers want. The loan is to purchase inventory such as candy, juices, crackers and other products. Together, she and her friend have decided to take out this loan, which is very helpful. Josefa has been selling tortillas for over 9 years. She is a very hard working woman. They dream of continuing their business, which is very important to them both.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: inventory

loans.name: Walter

texts.es: El sr, Walter R. T. su negocio es taller de soldadura el repara las plataforma de los camiones de carga pesada, mofles, motor todo lo que se refiere de soldadura de vehículo, el crédito lo está solicitando para comprar un soldador y hacer un pozo de agua en su casa el tiene su propio taller ubicado en el municipio de san Rafael consta con tres personas que le ayudan que son mecanico. El trabaja como ayudante en un taller de soldadura una vez que el aprendio este oficio decidió tener su propio taller y tenia unos ahorrito y realizo un crédito para ajustar y comprar sus herramienta que eran necesaria para el trabajo ya si fue poco a poco surgiendo los crédito que ceprodel le ha otorgado le han sido de mucha ayuda. Es casado y le tiene2 hijos los dos en edad escolar ya ha tenido 6 creditos con nosotros y le han impactado mucho en su negocio y en su vida familiar ya que con sus ingresos del negocio a podido ir construyendo su casa.
texts.en:
Walter R. T.'s business is a welding workshop. He repairs the beds of heavy trucks, mufflers, motors or anything with regards to vehicle welding. The loan that he is requesting is for purchase of a soldering iron and to build a water well in his home. He has his own shop located in the town of San Rafael. He has three people who help him who are mechanics. He worked as an apprentice in a welding shop. Once he learned this job, he decided to start his own shop and he had a little savings and took out a loan to make for the difference and bought the tools that were necessary for the job. The loan that Ceprodel granted has been very helpful. He is married and has two children who are school age. He has had six loans with us, which have had great impact on his business and in his family life since with the income from his business he's been able to build his house.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a soldering iron and build a water well.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of televisions and beauty products

loans.name: La Buena Fe Group

texts.en:
Isemaline is the coordinator of her group, La Buena Fe (Good Faith), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areaas surrounding El-Seibo, a rural town where the economy is dominated by agriculture and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and their three children.

Isemaline is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business (selling food at a stand) by purchasing cooking oil, soups, vegetables and rice. She will use the profits to invest in her children by purchasing school supplies and in her business which she would like to make bigger. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil, soups, rice, and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy beauty products

loans.name: Los Coquitos Group

texts.es: El grupo Solidario Los Coquitos lo conforman Paz Catalina de 67 años y Mayra Modesta de 36 años. Ambas se dedican a diferentes actividades económicas, por lo que este no es el primer financiamiento que realizan ya que ha sido de gran progreso para las dos. Ellas son personas muy humildes y trabajan para proporcionarles a sus hijos los estudios y alimentos diario, por lo que ellas no tuvieron la oportunidad de estudiar. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de materia prima. El deseo de ellas es que las personas que siempre están ayudando a otras a salir adelante continúen apoyando para mejorar sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
The Solidarity Group “Los Coquitos” (The Little Coconuts) consists of Paz Catalina, who is 67 years old, and Mayra Modesta, who is 36 years old. Both women are engaged in different businesses, so this is not the first time they have received financing. They have made great progress as a result.

Both women are humble individuals who work to educate and feed their children since they did not have the opportunity to attend school. The loan being requested will be used as operating capital to purchase raw materials. Their wish is to see people always help one another succeed and continue to support each other in improving their living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Blessing Children Group

texts.en:
Watta K. is 40 years old and married with three children whose ages range from nine to 18 years old.  Her children are all in school, with the youngest in fifth grade and the oldest a freshman in the university.  Watta herself was never able to go to school and has difficulty reading and writing.

Watta started her business selling cloth, fabric, thread, and linen about 21 years ago with $40 U.S. in starter capital provided by her father as a wedding gift.  Watta sells at the Red Light Market, a bustling area full of shops, stalls, and tabletop and mobile sellers and trades people.  Red Light is Liberia's largest market and is on the outskirts of Monrovia, the capital of the country.  Watta credits her success at business with talking to customers in a polite manner.

Watta plans to use her 12,000 Liberian dollar share of this 60,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy trousers, wedding garments, and other goods for her business.  Someday, she dreams of getting into real estate as a business.  She also hopes that she will continue to be successful enough to support her children so they can improve their lives.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Watta is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy clothes, fabric, thread, and linen.

loans.name: Marie Claire

texts.fr: Née en 1975, T. Marie Claire est mariée à YOVO G. Raoufou un cuisinier. Le couple a six enfants tous scolarisés, dont quatre sont à sa charge. La famille vit ensemble depuis trois ans à Djèrègbé Gbokpa, sur la route de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la maison. N'ayant jamais fréquenté l'école, Marie Claire mène comme activité la vente de nourriture (riz, accompagné de poissons frits et de sauce) à l'école primaire publique d'Agonkanmè à Porto-Novo. Marie Claire s'approvisionne au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin. Marie Claire mène cette activité depuis 5 ans, mais n'a encore jamais bénéficié d'un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de ses élèves, Marie Claire ambitionne agrandir son activité et mieux satisfaire ses clients. C'est la raison pour laquelle Marie Claire sollicite un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1975, Marie Claire T. is married to G. Raoufou YOVO, a cook. The couple have six children, all educated, of which four are under her care. The whole family has been living for the past three years in Djèrègbé Gbokpa, on the road to Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Benin. The couple share household expenses. As she never attended school, Marie Claire’s activity is selling food (rice, accompanied by fried fish and sauce) at the public primary school of Agonkanmé in Porto-Novo. Marie Claire has been doing this for five years, but has never requested a loan from ALIDé before. Facing an escalating demand from the pupils, Marie Claire wishes to expand her activity and improve the satisfaction of her customers. For this reason she is requesting a first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice and sauce condiments (tomatoes, chili peppers, onions, oil, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es: La Sra. Patricia F. Duarte. Tiene dos hijos en edades escolares y ella y su esposo se dedican a compra y venta de materiales de construcción, negocio que lo han ampliado con  CEPRODEL, con esta actividad han logrado mayores ingresos económicos los cuales han permitido hacer mejoras en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Patricia F. D.has two children who are school age and she and her husband are dedicated to buying and selling construction materials, a business that they have expanded with Ceprodel. With this activity, they have secured greater economic income which has allowed them to improve their home.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Bienestar En Dios 7 Group

texts.en:
Angelita is the coordinator of her group, Bienestar en Dios (Wellbeing with God), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding El-Seibo, where the economy is dominated by agriculture and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her family.

Angelita is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and she is excited for the opportunity to grow her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business (selling clothing and perfume) by purchasing the large assorted packs of clothing that often come from American Salvation Army stores and perfumes that she will sell in her community. She will use the profits to invest in constructing her own home as well as paying tuition at the local university where she is taking classes. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy used clothing and perfumes to sell

loans.name: Silvia Patricia

texts.es:
El banco comunal Creciendo para el Futuro fue fundado en la ciudad de Portoviejo, este banco se reúne en un sector llamado Parque Forestal a las afueras de la ciudad está integrado por 20 socias entre ellas la señora Silvia Rodríguez hace dos  ciclos.

Silvia está casada desde hace 13 años y es madre de tres  niños, su esposo trabaja en la construcción de viviendas y ella a mas de ser  ama de casa también se dedica a su pequeña tienda  donde vende  productos de primera necesidad, lácteos, carnes, y más, este negocio lo monto incentivada por su mamá quien le dio un lugar en su casa evitándole pagar arriendo ya son   dos años con su negocio y le va muy bien,  y con la  ayuda que le brinda la fundación ha podido seguir surtiendo de mercadería e ir incrementando un poquito más cada día, nos comenta que empezó con 300 dólares  y ahora la inversión es mayor. 

Con este nuevo préstamo nuestra socia  comprará  a los distribuidores arroz, azúcar, aceite, sal, agua, harinas, etc. para abastecer su negocio y brindar más y mejores productos a sus clientes, su horario de atención es todos los días de 7 am a 8pm porlo que debe trasladarse de su casa a casa de su madre a pocas cuadras para atender su negocio.

El sueño de Silvia es algún día tener un restaurante pues a  ella le gusta preparar  alimentos, desea que su sueño se haga realidad por eso esta ahorrando para lograrlo.
texts.en:
The communal bank called "Growing for the Future" is based in the city of Portoviejo. This bank meets in a sector called Forest Park on the outskirts of the city. It is composed of 20 associates, among them the lady Silvia R. for two loan cycles. Silvia has been married for 13 years and is the mother of three children. Her husband works in home construction and she has to be more than a housewife also. She is dedicated to their small store where she sells convenience products, milk, meats, and more. This business was started at the urging of her mom who gave them a place in her house for the store so they would not have to pay rent. Already they have had the business for two years and it goes very well. With the aid that the foundation offers, she has been able to continue supplying merchandise and to grow a little bit more each day. She tells us that she began with 300 dollars and now her investment is greater. With this new loan she will buy rice, sugar, oil, salt, water, flour, etc. wholesale to supply her business and to offer more and better products to her clients. Her schedule of service is every day from 7 am to 8pm, for which she leaves her home and goes to her mother's house a few blocks away to tend her business. The dream of Silvia is to some day have a restaurant, since she likes to prepare food. She would like this dream to become reality therefore she is saving to achieve it.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: the purchase of rice, sugar, oil, salt, water, flour, etc for resale in her convenience store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying mechanics supplies and equipment

loans.name: Yameliz

texts.es: La Sra. Yameliz R. Z. solicito crédito para comprar y vender materiales de construcción en Managua a las fábricas de bloques, ladrillos, letrinas lavanderos y otros productos que ofrecen las empresas de construcción. Anteriormente era ama de casa y no contribuía a generar otras fuentes de ingreso en la familia, es el octavo crédito con Ceprodel, ella tiene 3 hijos en edades escolares y solicita este préstamo para generar más ingresos al núcleo familiar
texts.en:
Mrs. Yameliz R. Z. applied for credit to buy and sell construction materials in Managua at the factories that make cinder blocks, bricks, latrines, wash houses and other products that the construction companies offer. She was a housewife before and did not contribute generating other sources of income for the family. This is her eighth credit with Ceprodel. She has 3 school-aged children. She is applying for this loan to generate more income for her nuclear family.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy more Construction materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying photographic equipment

loans.name: God Grace Group

texts.en:
Mary S. is a leader of a group of five borrowers called God Grace. She is 49 years old and is a single mother with two children aged 28 and 30 years old.  Both of her children are college graduates and now working.  Mary also cares for two siblings.

Mary and her family live and work in the New Matadi Fanti town community, about two miles away from downtown Monrovia, Liberia. This is a community that is full of Fanti tribespeople from Ghana (a West African nation close to Liberia). Mary is also a college graduate herself.

Mary’s business is the sale of food such as rice, oil, onion, etc. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail in the New Matadi Fanti town.   She has been running this business for five years and hopes to improve business to a shop in the near future.

Mary started selling with only a bucket of pepper but now, she sells different kinds of food. She sells at a good location and has a good business relationship with her clients in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Mary needs this loan to purchase more goods for resale.  She dreams of being well known in society.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mary is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, oil, and onions for resale

loans.name: Felix Adrian

texts.es:
El Sr. Felix es casado vive en un casa en anticretico en la localidad de San José distante a 2 Km. De El Torno, su esposa es de profesión Farmacéutica y desea muy pronto tener su propia farmacia, ella   trabaja en una farmacia y con esta actividad le ayuda con los gastos del hogar.

El negocio del Sr Felix es el servicio de Internet cuenta con algunas computadoras y una de sus metas es crecer en su negocio y poder comprarse muchos mas equipos de computacion. 

El Sr. Felix tiene un terreno donde pronto comenzaran a construir su vivienda y esto le ocasionara muchos gastos por la compra de material de construccion, por esta razon trabaja mucho.

El destino del crédito fue para compra dos computadoras para su punto Internet ya que  las que tiene no le abastecen para cubrir la demanda de cliente.

Esta agradecido con Emprender y con Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Mr. Felix is married and lives in a rented house in the town of San José which is 2 Km. from El Torno. His wife is a pharmacist and would like to have her own pharmacy very soon. She works in a pharmacy and, with this job, can help him with the household expenses. Mr. Felix’s business is an Internet service. He has some computers and one of his goals is to grow his business to be able to buy more computer equipment. Mr. Felix has land where he will soon begin to build his home. This will create a lot of expenses to buy the construction material and that is why he works a lot. The loan was to buy two computers for his internet service since he couldn’t cover customer demand with the ones he had. He is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for their confidence shown by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUY COMPUTER EQUIPMENT

loans.name: Santos Esxequiel

texts.es:
EL SEÑOR SANTOS TIENE EL NEGOCIO DE SERVICIO DONDE ES EL SECTOR TRANSPORTE 
EL CREDITO LO INVERTIRA PARA MEJORAR SU VEHICULO Y ASI PODER DAR UN MEJOR SERVICIO Y A TENCION A SUS CLIENTES, EL CREDITO LE AYUDARA A TENER UN MAYOR INGRESO PARA SU FAMILIA EL ES PADRE SOLTERO Y TIENE UNA NIÑA DE TRES AÑOS DE EDAD A LA CUAL AMA MUCHO  Y ES POR ELLA QUE EL QUIERE MEJORAR SU CALIDAD DE VIDA POR MEDIO DEL FINANCIAMIENTO, SU TRABAJO EMPIEZA DESDE HORAS MUY TEMPRANA (CINCO DE LA MAÑANA) Y TERMINA SU LABOR A LAS OCHO DE LA NOCHE YA QUE EL REALIZA VIAJES A LOS DIFERENTES LUGARES DEL SECTOR.
texts.en:
MR. SANTOS HAS A SERVICE BUSINESS IN THE TRANSPORTATION SECTOR. HE WILL INVEST THE LOAN TO IMPROVE HIS VEHICLE TO BE ABLE TO GIVE BETTER SERVICE AND ATTENTION TO HIS CUSTOMERS. THE LOAN WILL HELP HIM HAVE A LARGER INCOME FOR HIS FAMILY. HE IS A SINGLE FATHER. HE HAS A THREE-YEAR-OLD DAUGHTER WHICH HE LOVES VERY MUCH AND HE WANTS TO IMPROVE HIS QUALITY OF LIFE FOR HER THROUGH THE FINANCING. HIS JOB STARTS VERY EARLY (FIVE IN THE MORNING) AND HE FINISHES WORK AT EIGHT IN THE EVENING SINCE HE TRAVELS TO DIFERENT PLACES IN THE SECTOR.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUY TIRES, SHOCK ABSORBERS, PUMP, ALTERNATOR, AND HOSES

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: We Are One Group

texts.en:
Farze Z. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called We Are One. She is 40 years old and is married with six children aged two to 23 years old. Their educational levels are kindergarten  through 11th grade.  Farze herself did not continue her education beyond seventh grade due to pregnancy.   Farze and her family live and work on Front Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia.  

Farze’s business is the sale of general goods such as pomades, styling gel, candles, matches, torch lights, etc. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail to residents of Front Street in Monrovia.  She has been running this business for more than 10 years and hopes to own a shop in the near future.

Farze started by selling alcoholic drinks and her capital was 3,000 Liberian Dollars that was given to her by her brother.   She talks to her customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.  Farze needs this loan to purchase more general goods such as pomades, styling gel, candles, for resale.  She dreams of educating her children and building a house for them.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Farze is the one holding the sign.  Lorpu M. is inset at lower right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more general goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of alcoholic drinks

loans.name: Faithful Business Group

texts.en: Jacob J. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called the Faithful Business Group. He is 34 years old and married with two children, who are 8 and 5 years old and in kindergarten and third grade. Jacob and his family live in the Freeport Community, near the Sea Port of Monrovia and located close to downtown Monrovia. He works at the intersection of Randall and Water Street in downtown Monrovia. Jacob is a high school graduate. Jacob’s business is the sale of food such as rice, beans, etc. He buys his goods from wholesalers and sells retail on a table in downtown Monrovia. He has been running this business for 16 years and hopes to become an importer and exporter of general goods to Liberia in the near future. Jacob started selling with 4000.00 Liberian Dollars as working capital but now operates with 12000.00 Liberian Dollars. He has faced difficulty with siting his business, because he does not have a stable site. He sells quality goods and interacts with his customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from him. Jacob needs this loan to purchase more rice, oil, beans, etc., for resale. He dreams and hopes that he and his family will remain in good health. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Jacob is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP, a Kiva partner, seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, oil, beans and other foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Mother Blessing Group

texts.en:
Mark F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Mother Blessing. He is 22 years old and is engaged with no children but he cares for a niece.  He could not continue his education past the sixth grade due to lack of financial support.  Mark and his fiancé live in the Redlight community near Monrovia, and he works in the Redlight market, the largest market in Liberia.  

Mark’s business is tabletop sales of general goods such as sardines, candles, insecticides, etc. He buys his goods from wholesalers and sells retail in the Redlight market.  He has been running this business for more than two years and hopes to own a shop in the near future.

Mark started as a salesman, saved, and later decided to do his own business. And he started out selling with only a single bag of sugar.  He is a very friendly person to his customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from him.  Mark needs this loan to purchase more sardines, candles, insecticides other items for resale.  He dreams of giving his family the best help he can to improve their lives.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mark is the one holding the sign.  Patricia K. is inset at lower right. 

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more sardines, candles, insecticides etc

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of motor oil

loans.name: Jesus Nelson

texts.es:
El Señor Jesus es cliente antiguo en la institucion, esta casado y tiene hijos mayores y otros que se encuentran en edad escolar, es una persona muy responsable y trabajadora se dedica al servicio de transporte urbano tiene su auto trabajando en un radio taxi, todos los dias sale muy temprano hasta las 18:00, a partir de esa hora el retorna a su domicilio para poder ayudar a su esposa y a sus hijos.

Su sueño es poder comprar dos vehiculos más para entregarles a sus hijos mayores para que tambien puedan trabajar y asi puedan pagar sus estudios e independisarse. 

El Sr. Jesus necesita el credito para poder cambiar llantas y hacer algunos arreglos a la movilidad para seguir ofreciendo un excelente servicio a sus clientes.

Esta muy agradecido con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Jesus is an established client with the institution. He is married and has adult children and others who are school aged. He is a very responsible and hardworking person who works in city transportation. His car is part of the radio taxi pool. He leaves early every day and works until 6pm. Then he returns home to help his wife and his children. His dream is to be able to purchase two more cars and give them to his eldest sons so that can also work and be able to pay for their schooling and become independent. Jesus needs a loan to be able to change his tires and make some repairs to his car in order to be able to continue offering excellent services to his customers. He is very thankful to Emprender and Kiva for their trust they put in him by extending him the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle maintenance

loans.name: Helping Unity Group

texts.en:
Siah F. is a leader of a group of five borrowers called Helping Unity. She is 44 years old and is married with six children aged seven to 25 years old. Their educational levels are third grade through high school graduate. Siah also cares for two nieces and a nephew.

Siah herself did not go to school due to poverty. She and her family live in the Redlight Wood Camp community and she works in the Redlight market, the largest market in Liberia.  

Siah’s business is the sales of general goods such as hardware and used clothes from a table at the market. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail in the Redlight market.  She has been running this business for more than 20 years and hopes to own a shop in the near future.

Siah started her business dealings with only 20 Liberian dollars that she used to purchase eight pieces of used clothes which she sold for 10 Liberian Dollars each. It was at that point that she grew the momentum to do business.  She talks to her customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.  Siah needs this loan to purchase additional hardware and used clothes for resale.  She dreams of giving her children a good education.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Siah is the one holding the sign.  Joseph F. is inset at lower right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional hardware and used clothes for resale.

loans.name: Divino Niño Group

texts.es: El Banco Comunal “DIVINO NIÑO” está ubicado por una avenid, todas las socias son del mismo barrio, las socias son  muy unidas, es un grupo muy organizado, es su 1º ciclo son personas dedicadas a trabajar, para engrandecer su negocio Maria Roció es la Presidenta es una persona muy responsable, Yaneth es la Secretaria, y Susana es la Tesorera. Todas las socias del Banco Comunal tienen negocio, como ser: Venta de Comida, Venta de ropa, Venta de carne, Venta de bebidas, Ventas de Yerbas Medicinales. En detalle se puede mencionar que Maria rocio (la presidenta) se dedica a la venta de licores de diferentes tipos esta actividad la realiza desde hace 6 años atrás, Ilaria se dedica a la venta de comida desde hace 10 años, Lucy luciel vende carne y tiene experiencia en esta negocio de 2 años, Yaneth se dedica a la venta de yerbas medicinales y de otros tipos desde hace 4 años atrás, Edmundo	se dedica a la venta de carne desde hace 10 años atrás, Veronica vende quesillo recién desde hace 1 año, Beatriz se dedica a ofrecer a sus clientes una variedad de abarrotes desde hace 	5 años, Ana karen tiene su peluquería donde atiende esmeradamente a sus clientes desde hace 3 años, Maribel se dedica a la venta soda desde hace 1 año atrás y por último está nuestra socia Susana que se dedica a la venta de ropa importada desde hace un año. Las socias indican que si tienen mucha competencia pero que igual siguen trabajando día a día para hacer crecer sus respectivos negocios y actividades. El crédito por lo general lo utilizan como capital de operaciones para prosperar su negocio, aumentar su capital, y poder surtir más su negocio. En su mayoría trabajan con otras Instituciones financieras y nuestra Instrucción pero ellas muestran un antecedente crediticio muy bueno, además que son responsables con el pago de sus cuotas.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank "Divino Niño" is located on an avenue. All of the members are from the same neighborhood, and they are very close. It is a very organized group and this is their first loan cycle. They are dedicated to working and growing their businesses. Maria Roció is the President and she is a very responsible person. Yaneth is the Secretary and Susana is the Treasurer. All of the members of the Communal Bank have a business such as: Food sales, clothing sales, meat sales, beverage sales, and herbal medicine sales. In particular, Maria Roció (the President) has been selling various types of liquors for 6 years. Ilaria has been selling meals for 10 years. Lucy sells meat and has had this business for 2 years. Yaneth has been selling herbal medicines and other herbs for 4 years. Edmundo has been selling meat for 10 years. Veronica has been selling cheese for 1 year. Beatriz has sold a variety of groceries for the past 5 years. Ana Karen has a salon where she has been enthusiastically attending to her customers for 3 years. Maribel has been selling soda for 1 year, and finally Susana has been selling imported clothing for 1 year. The members say that they have a lot of competition, but the keep working every day to grow their respective businesses and activities. The loan will be used in general as operating capital to help their businesses thrive, to increase their capital and to be able to offer more selection. Most of the members work with other financial institutions in addition to ours, but they have a very good credit history and are very responsible about making their payments.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of dental instruments and products

loans.name: Nuevo Horizonte Group

texts.es: El grupo Nuevo Horizonte se caracteriza por ser muy unido, y por tener negocios en la misma zona central D. la localidad, una parte del grupo vive en alquiler, algunos en casa prestada pueD. ser D. suegros o padres, algunos en casa propia. El grupo está compuesto por 10 socios D. los cuales 3 son varones y 7 son mujeres, la mitad D. las socias se dedican al negocio D. la venta D. alimentos tipo snack, el resto se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes y comercio D. computadora. Marisel Shirley que es la presidenta del grupo es una promotora  mayorista D. tarjetas D. teléfono desD. hace 10 años, Julia atienD. en su snack desD. hace 15 años, AyD. tiene su frial y también una tienda D. artículos en general esto desD. hace 10 años, Leoncia	se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes con una antigüedad en el rubro D. 20 años, Amanda	es comerciante	desD. hace 6 años, Marcia Olivia es comerciante D. calzados desD. hace 3 años atrás, Maria angelica se dedica al comercio D. ropa y tiene una experiencia D. 20 años en este rubro, Ross Aurelio venD. 	equipos informáticos con una experiencia D. 6 años, Freddy atienD. su pensión donD. ofrece almuerzos y otros platos esto desD. hace 23 años, Nestor Hector tiene una vidriería que atienD. hace 15 años. Como se pueD. ver el grupo en general tiene bastante experiencia en sus respectivos grupos. La competencia como en todo negocio a nivel nacional está presente pero lo bueno es que tienen sus temporadas y este grupo va a invertir para tener ingresos en las fiestas carnavaleras. El crédito es utilizado para la compra D. mas mercadería para surtir un puesto D. ingreso como por ejemplo un snack, una proveedora D. alimentos que tiene puesto en el mercado y los comerciantes D. computadoras para la compra D. accesorios que luego comercializa, el que hace trabajos D. vidrios comprara marcos y vidrios para la venta y para sus trabajos que mensualmente tiene. Las personas negociantes que solicitan créditos en agrocapital esperan ver mejorar sus negocios con la ayuda del crédito que se les otorga, esperan ver mejorar a sus hijos en la educación y mejorar su forma D. vida, aumentar y ampliar sus negocios. Estas personas componentes del grupo son personas con experiencia en créditos y están muy acostumbrados a trabajar con créditos ya que saben utilizarlo en sus negocios.
texts.en:
The group "Nuevo Horizonte" (New Horizon) is very close and the members have businesses in the same central area of their town. Some of the group lives in rented homes, others in houses loaned to them by in-laws or parents, and others own their own homes. The group is maD. up of 10 members, of whom 3 are men and 7 are women. Half of the members sell snack food, the rest sell groceries and have a computer business. Marisel Shirley, the president of the group, has been a wholesaler of telephone cards for the past 10 years. Julia has had a snack business for 15 years. AyD. has a snack shop and has also had a general store for 10 years. Leoncia has been selling groceries for about 20 years. Amanda has had a business for 6 years. Marcia Olivia has sold shoes for 3 years. Maria Angelica sells clothing and has been in this business for 20 years. Ross Aurelio has been selling computer equipment for 6 years. Freddy has had a small restaurant where he offers lunches and other meals for 23 years. Nestor Hector has been making glass for 15 years. As you can see, in general the group has a great deal of experience in their respective areas. As with all businesses in the country, there is competition, but the good thing is that each group has its season. This group is going to invest in order to make money during the Carnival parties. The loan will be used to purchase more merchandise to stock a business such as a snack stand, or for a person who makes meals to have a stand in the market. The people with computer businesses will purchase accessories that they will sell, the glass maker will purchase frames and glass for sale and for his monthly jobs. The business people who request loans from Agrocapital hope to improve their businesses with the help of the loan. They hope to improve their children's education, improve their quality of life, and to grow and expand their businesses. The members of this group are experienced with loans and are very accustomed to working with loans as they already know how to use them in their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Unidos Podemos 9 Group

texts.en:
Maritza is the coordinator of her group Unidos Podemos (United We Can), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding El-Seibo, a rural town where the economy is dominated by agriculture and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and their two children.

Maritza is excited to be taking her third loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a small colmado or cornerstore, by supplying it with cooking oil, rice, beans, powdered milk and other basic necessities. She will use the profits to save towards investing in a separate location for her colmado, which she currently runs out of her house. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy, cooking oil, vegetables, powedered milk, beans

loans.name: Rayos Del Sol Group

texts.es: El Banco Comunal “RAYOS DEL SOL” está ubicado en un lugar denominado la  Pampa, todas las socias  son del Barrio, es un grupo muy organizado, ya van por el 2º ciclo son personas dedicadas a trabajar, Katherina es la Presidenta, Bárbara es la Secretaria, y Laura es la Tesorera. Todas las socias del Banco Comunal tienen negocio, como ser: Venta D. regalos, Venta D. ropa interior, Venta D. bordados en vestidos. En detalle podemos mencionar lo siguiente: Katherina	como indicamos anteriormente es la presidenta y ella tiene un bazar surtido donD. ofrece una variedad D. regalos para distintas edades y eventos esta actividad la realiza desD. hace 3 años atrás, Yoisy se dedica a la venta D. comida desD. hace 2 años, Maria cristina venD. ropa desD. hace 3 años, Angelica se dedica a la venta D. comida desD. hace 1 año, Jessica venD. desayunos en un puesto en el mercado desD. hace 2 años atrás, Cinthia se dedica a la venta D. ropa desD. hace 7 años atrás, Barbara se dedica a la venta D. comida desD. hace 1 año, Claudia maria se dedica a la venta D. comida desD. hace 5 años, Leopoldo es taxista y se desempeña como chofer desD. hace 8 años atrás, Laura Alejandra tiene un puesto donD. venD. ropa interior desD. hace 1 año, Silvana venD. ropa nueva que trae D. otra ciudad desD. hace 2 años y por último nuestra socia Cintia que se dedica al negocio D. las comidas desD. hace 1 año. Las socias indican D. que si tienen mucha competencia. Para algunas no les perjudica en nada pese a eso ellas siguen trabajando esto debido a que su antigüedad les permite tener experiencia en sus respectivos negocios y también ayuda porque la mayoría cuenta con clientela fija. El crédito por lo general lo utilizan para hacer crecer su negocio, aumentar su capital. En su mayoría trabajan con otras Instituciones microfinancieras y nuestra Instrucción pero ellas muestran un antecedente crediticio bueno.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Rayos del Sol” (Rays of Sun) is located in a place called La Pampa. All of the members are from this neighborhood. They are an organized group of working people who are starting their second loan cycle. Katherina is the President, Bárbara is the Secretary, and Laura is the Treasurer. All of the members have retail businesses selling products such as gifts, undergarments, and embroidered dresses. The specific details are as follows:

As stated before, Katherina is the President. She manages a bazaar where she offers a variety of gifts for different ages and occasions. Her business has been in existence for three years.

Yoisy has been selling food for two years.

Maria Cristina has been selling clothing for three years.

Angelica has been selling food for one year.

Jessica has been selling breakfasts from a stall at the market for over two years.

Cinthia has been selling clothing for seven years.

Barbara has been selling food for one year.

Claudia Maria has been selling food for five years.

Leopold is a taxi driver and has been offering transportation services for eight years.

Laura Alejandra has a vending location where she has been selling undergarments for one year.

Silvana sells new clothing that she brings in from another city. She has been doing this for two years.

Finally, Cynthia has been in the food business for one year.

The members have indicated that they face stiff competition. For some, the competition does not bother them because they continue to work as a result of their experience. Many of them already have an established customer base. This loan will be used to grow their businesses by increasing their operating capital. Most of the members have worked with other microfinance institutions and developed good credit histories.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.es:
Alejandra B. P., tiene la edad de 55 años, es casada, y tiene 1 hijo mayor de edad, que es su mayor prioridad. Además de vivir con su esposo, tienen a cargo un nieto de 5 años.  El crédito lo quiere para la compra de  ganado para cría.El negocio del ganado le ayudará a su familia ya que cuando pueda vender sus crías van a obtener mayores ganancias. No es la primera vez doña Alejandra se financia con  FUDECOSUR, ella manifiesta que el comité de crédito le ha ayudado mucho y que le han brindado muchas facilidades. Ella tambien se dedica a la costura, desde que estaba joven cose, pero quiere entrar al negocio del ganado.
Ella espera que con este proyecto crezca y así pueda en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mejor estabilidad económica.

About FUDECOSUR:
The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Alejandra B. P. is 55 years old, married, and has one adult child who is her highest priority. Besides living with her husband, she also takes care of her five year old grandson. This loan will be used to buy cattle to raise. Her family will be able to earn more income when they go to sell the calves.

This is not the first time Sra. Alejandra has received a loan from FUDECOSUR. She said that the credit committee has helped her a lot and provided her with many services. Alejandra is also a seamstress and has been sewing since she was a young woman, but she wants to enter the cattle business. She hopes this project will grow so that her family will have a better quality of life and improved financial stability in the future.

About FUDECOSUR: The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cattle

loans.name: El Carmen Group

texts.es: El grupo Solidario El Carmen lo conforman Karen y Pía Bonifacia. Ellas se han unido para realizar un financiamiento que les será de mucha ayuda a las dos. Con mucho amor son personas que trabajan humildemente en sus negocios, Pía se dedica a la venta de ropa, desde hace 29 años ella visita las comarcas más cercanas para ofrecer sus productos, pues a pesar de que tiene que caminar mucho no se detiene porque sabe que tiene proporcionar el alimento diario de su familia, pues la mayoría de sus clientes son muy tranquilos y cariñosos con Pía ya que tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar en esta actividad. El financiamiento que solicitan es para la compra de mercaderías necesarias para sus negocios.
texts.en:
The Solidarity Group “El Carmen” consists of Karen and Pía Bonifacia. They have joined together to receive a loan that will be helpful to both of them. These loving women work humbly in their businesses. Pía has been selling clothes for 29 years. She travels to nearby districts to offer her products. Even though her job requires a lot of walking, Pía continues to work because she knows this is her way of putting food on the table for her family every day. Most of Pía’s customers are very calm and considerate when dealing with her because they know she does a lot of walking in her work.

The loan being requested will be used to buy the necessary goods for their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for their businesses

loans.name: Paraiso De La Constancia Group

texts.es:
Isabel, se dedica a la venta D. Productos Lácteos, tiene 3 hijos D. 19, 12 y 2 años. Isabel inició su negocio vendiendo queso, con el capital que recibió D. FINCA ha podido comprarse una procesadora D. yogurt, venD. sus productos al por mayor en Lircay. A pesar D. ser sola (sin pareja) mantiene a sus hijos. Con el préstamo que va a recibir va a comprar etiquetas para empacar sus productos en envases plásticos y botellas. Su sueño es tener su propia fábrica D. productos lácteos y tener una ONG para ayudar a sus compañeras y darles trabajo.

Raymunda se dedica a la venta D. carne, leche, queso y huevos, es casada y tiene 8 hijos D. entre 2 y 17 años D. edad, antes Raimunda solo vendía 50 quesos, gracias a los préstamo que recibe, pueD. invertir y actualmente venD. carne, 200 quesos y 200 huevos diarios, esto le ha permitido mejorar su vida económica y social, con el préstamo actual quiere comprar una vaca lechera e incrementar su negocio con mas gallinas. Su sueño es ver a sus hijos hombres D. bien y profesionales.

Florentina es casada, tiene 12 hijos D. 6 la menor y 33 el mayor, inició su negocio vendiendo ropa interior, antes no sabía leer, ahora venD. ropa y tiene un puesto propio en el mercado. Actualmente se está recuperando D. una operación D. apendicitis. Aprovecha los préstamos para invertir en su negocio, su sueño es tener una tienda muy surtida D. ropa, que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Isabel sells dairy products. She has three children who are 19, 12, and 2 years of age. Isabel started selling cheese, but she used the funding she received from FINCA to purchase a device for processing yogurt. She sells her products wholesale in Lircay. Despite being alone (without a spouse), she is able to support her children. With the loan she will receive, Isabel will buy labels to place on her products that are packaged in plastic containers and bottles. Her dreams incluD. owning a dairy factory and seeing an NGO help her friends by providing them work.

Raymunda sells meat, milk, cheese, and eggs. She is married and has eight children who range in age from 2 to 17. Before Raymunda only sold 50 blocks of cheese, but thanks to the loans that she has received, she now sells 200 blocks of cheese and 200 eggs a day. This has allowed her to improve her economic situation and social standing. With the current loan, she will buy a dairy cow to increase her business as well as more chickens. Her goal is to see her sons become outstanding professional men.

Florentina is married and has twelve children ranging in age from 6 to 33. She started her business selling undergarments. Previously she was not able to read, but now she sells clothing and has her own vending stall at the market. Florentina is currently recovering from an appendectomy. She has taken advantage of the loans to invest in her business. Her dreams are to have a well-stocked clothing store and see her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Digna Esperanza

texts.es: Digna Esperanza tiene 63 años, tiene 3 hijos y todos trabajan de manera independiente. Su actividad económica es la venta de repostería y comida. Hace más de 18 años que se dedica a este negocio, ella se levanta temprano todos los días pues tiene que limpiar su hogar y además su negocio, ya que la mayoría de sus clientes asisten muy temprano a su local para realizar la compra de sus deliciosas reposterías. Ella solicita este financiamiento específicamente para capital de trabajo ya que invertirá en materia prima necesaria para su negocio. su deseo es proporcionarle mejoras a su humilde vivienda.
texts.en:
Digna Esperanza is 63 years old and has three children who all work independently. She sells baked goods and food. Her business has been in operation for more than 18 years. Digna wakes up early every morning to clean her house and then proceeds to her business. Most of her customers arrive at her shop early to purchase her delicious pastries.

She is requesting a loan specifically to use as operating capital to buy raw materials for her business. Her wish is to make improvements to her modest home.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for her business

loans.name: Anccaras Group

texts.es:
María, es conviviente, tiene 2 hijos D. 7 años y 1 año.
