loans.name: Pha

texts.en: Pha P. is 52 years old and she lives in Melong Khang Cheung village in Takeo province. Her husband, Sang Soun, is laborer in the local village. Pha lives with her husband and five children, one of whom is employed in the garment factory, three of whom are students at the local school, while the fifth child is a farmer. Pha is a rice middleman. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it and is requesting a loan to buy more rice to sell for better income. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy more rice for resale

loans.name: Dy

texts.en: Mrs. Dy T. is 45 years old and she lives in Melong Khang Cheung village in Takeo province. She is the mother of three children, one of whom is a laborer, while another does housework and the third is a student at the local school.  Mrs. Dy T. and her husband, Mr. Sokhom T., are farmers who own a three-hectare field on which to cultivate rice. With this farm, they do not have enough money to support it. So, Mrs. Dy T. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a harvest machine for her first child to start business. Aside from the farm, this family owns a poultry business.

loans.use: To buy a harvest machine

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en: Mrs. Sopheap C. is 40 years old and she lives in Pou village in Takeo province. She is a grocer. Her husband, Mr. Samith Nget, is a farmer who owns a one-hectare field on which to cultivate rice. Sopheap C. needs 1,000,000 Riel from AMK to support the rice crops, and, with the rest of the loan, she would buy more groceries to support her small business. With the loan, she hopes to improve her family's living conditions and increase her income, too. Sopheap C. has two children, one of whom is a student at the local school, while the youngest child is five years old.

loans.use: To support a rice farm and to buy more groceries for resale

loans.name: Ith

texts.en:
Mrs. Ith U. is a 57-year-old farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice in Trapeang Chrey village, Takeo province. She is the mother of five children: three are employed in the garment factory and the others are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. San Chhou, is a construction worker who has a small salary to support his family. 

Although this couple works hard, they do not earn enough income to support the family. So, Mrs. Ith U. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to be a motorbike taxi driver to increase their income and improve their standard of living. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to be a motorbike taxi driver

loans.name: Ry

texts.en:
Mrs. Ry N. is a 24-year-old farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. She lives with her husband in Thkov village in Takeo province. Her husband, Mr. Vuthy Kang, is a construction worker who earns a small salary to support the family. They have a child who is too young for school. In order to support the field, she decided to ask for a loan to buy two oxen to use as work animals on the farm. 
Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy two oxen to use as work animals

loans.name: Khorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Khorn H. is a 63-year-old widow living in Tonle village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. 

She tries to work hard at her farming but does not earn enough income to support herself. Therefore, Mrs. Khorn H. wants to start a new business to increase income and improve her standard of living. She decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Amalita

texts.en: Amalita O. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Amalita owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Amalita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Lin

texts.en:
Mrs. Lin C. is 43 years old and the mother of four children; two are employed at a garment factory and the others are students at the local school. They all live in Tonle village, Takeo province. 

Mrs. Lin C. is a farmer who owns two hectares for cultivating rice. Her husband, Mr. Thy Choun, is a palm juice collector. Mrs. Lin C. decided to ask for a loan from AMK to buy a motorbike for her husband to transport palm juice for sale. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to transport palm juice for sale

loans.name: Bibi Khadeja Group

texts.en:
The name of this group is Bibi Khadeja. It has three members. Together, they have requested a group loan of 30,000 AFN. 

Bibi Khadeja is the group leader. She is 39 years old, and is married with four children. She would like a loan to advance her quilt sewing business and buy materials.

The second member is Nazellah. She would like a loan for her tailoring business; she wants to buy a new sewing machine. 

The third member is Madena.  She would like a loan for her bakery, to buy firewood and a new shop. She hopes to have more clients and to increase her monthly income.

Finally, they would like to say that they admire the loan process in Afghanistan and its benefits for entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand and buy materials for a quilting business

loans.name: Rachaelanne

texts.en:
Rachaelanne L. is 23 years old, single, and from the village of Kinoguitan , Misamis Oriental Province.  To make a living, Rachaelanne owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products to members of the local community. Rachaelanne has had business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos a month from it.

In 2009, Rachaelanne joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rachaelanne is requesting a new loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos which she plans to use to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory for a "sari sari" (variety) shop.

loans.name: Anabelle

texts.en:
Anabelle U. is from the village of Balingasag , Misamis Oriental Province. She is 46 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Anabelle makes and sells food such as sweets, confectioneries, cookies and brownies. Her customers are residents of the local community. Anabelle has had her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month.

In 2009, Anabelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anabelle is requesting a loan of 5000 Philippine pesos which she plans to use to purchase raw ingredients for the sweets she makes. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anabelle from Kiva field partner HSPFI. If the loan helps to boost her business, she plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her operations.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make sweets, confectioneries, cookies and brownies.

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly S. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental Province. She is 45 years old, unmarried, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Beverly makes and sells snacks and other delicacies to members of the local community. Beverly has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Beverly joined Kiva field partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beverly is requesting a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos which she plans to use to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Beverly from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a snack business.

loans.name: Ostad Qasem Group

texts.en:
The Ostad Qasem group has four members. The group leader, Geti, is 34 years old, and lives in Kabul, Afghanistan.  She has three children.  Geti is seeking a loan to help develop her husband's dried-fruit business. Fawzya wants a loan to buy materials for her husband’s fresh-fruit business.  Norya and Nasera are seeking a loan for their tailoring business.  They need money to buy sewing materials and a new machine to replace one that doesn't work properly. The group members are confident that they can do the repayments on time.

 They would like to thank the Kiva lenders that support the entrepreneurs around Afghanistan.

loans.use: To help develop a dried-fruit business

loans.name: Bibi Gull Group

texts.en:
The Bibi G. group has four members. The group leader, Sha Jan, is 52 years old, and she has five children, two daughters and three sons. Sha Jan is seeking a loan for her husband’s vegetable-selling business.  She packs and cleans the vegetables and her husband sells them in the market. 

Makey wants a loan for her husband's general store, so that he can acquire more merchandise. Nafesa's loan request is for her tailoring business, so that she can buy a new sewing machine and a desk.  Bibi G. wants to take a loan for her husband’s fresh-fruit-selling business, so that he can get a new shop and improve his business. 

The group has requested a loan of 40,000 Afghanis.  They all would like to thank the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To improve a vegetable-selling business.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena D. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 30 years old. Lorena is married and has 2 adult children. Lorena owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lorena has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2009, Lorena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and giving her the ability to engage in business activities. Lorena is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Lorena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

Edna owns & operates specialized retail store selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

loans.name: Melodina

texts.en:
Melodina P. is from the village of P6, Brgy. 25 Gingoog City. She is 40 years old. Melodina is widowed and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Melodina owns & operates a business venture selling food products like a variety of viands. She peddles this food in the local community. Melodina has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melodina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Melodina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. She decides to request a loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Melodina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia O., 73, is making sure that she helps the families of her children.  She was once married to Jose O. Sr., who has passed away.  Tobether they had eight children. Now, in order to extend help to her grandchildren, she tries to make sure that she earns more than enough money for herself.  She has been managing her own variety store for 32 years.

Eugenia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than six years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow several times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy added stocks for her store.   

Eugenia is seeking an 8,000 Philippine peso loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying toiletries, basic commodities, and rice for her store.

She prays that her children can have jobs so that they can help with their family's expenses. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying toiletries, basic commodities, and rice for her store.

loans.name: Amina Farzad Group

texts.en:
The Amina Farzad group is made up of five female members. Lida, a hard-working 30-year-old woman, is the group leader.  She is a tailor and her business supports her husband and children. She will use a loan to buy sewing materials to improve her business. 
The second member of this group is Benafsha.  She has an embroidery business that she would like to expand.  
The third member is Saheda, who is seeking a loan to buy additional items for her husband's painting business and the last member is Shaziam who needs a loan for her bead-working business. 

All the group members would like to thank the Kiva lenders from their support.

loans.use: To buy sewing materials for a tailoring business.

loans.name: Amada

texts.en:
Amada G. is from the village of Guno-Cabilto St., Gingoog City. She is 67 years old. Amada is married and has 2 school-aged children. Amada owns and operates a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products in the local community. Amada has been involved in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Amada joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amada is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Amada from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

location.town: Guno, Cabilto St., Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana A., 43, is single but she makes sure that she can take care of herself and help her loved ones have a better life. She loves to cook and has been selling food for several years in her own small eatery.

Ana has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow 26 times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy ingredients for the food that she cooks to sell.   Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 18,000 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying food ingredients .

She dreams that her eatery will one day become a restaurant. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy food ingredients for her eatery business

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha Z., 51, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Constantino Z., a jeepney (small bus) driver, they are blessed with two children. In order to ensure that their family can have a better life, she helps her husband manage their jeepney business.

Editha has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than seven years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow 18 times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy auto parts for their jeep.   

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 25,000 loan. This amount will be used for registration expenses and the purchase of needed auto parts for their jeep.

Editha dreams that someday they will buy a van to be used as a transport service so that they will earn enough money to finance their children's college education. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: registration expenses and needed auto parts for their jeep

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 34 years old and married, and has an only child. He attended intermediate school and passed the final exam. 

He owns a women's clothing shop. He’s been in this business for more than three years. The purpose of this loan is to purchase more goods for his shop so he can attract more customers. Consequently, his family's income will increase. He is extremely ambitious and wants to expand and improve his shop, and begin to import various clothes for his shop. He has a good reputation in the market.

loans.use: To buy clothing and materials

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores R., 44, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Rolando R., a pedicab driver, they are blessed with one child. Dolores makes sure that she helps her husband earn an income so that their family can have a better life.  She has been selling ready-to-wear clothes and assorted cosmetics for two years.

Dolores has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than seven years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow 20 times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy added stock for her business.   Her two businesses let her earn a profit of PHP 10,000 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 24,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding businesses by buying assorted clothes and cosmetics products.

She dreams that her businesses will continue to grow so that they can help in providing for her family’s increasing needs. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buying assorted clothes and cosmetics products for her business

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina B., 67, is making sure that in spite of her old age, she can be self-sustaining to the point that she can help others as well. She has been managing her own variety store for 20 years.

Marina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than eight years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow 23 times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy stock for her store. Her business lets her earn a net profit of 2,900 Philippine pesos per month.  

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 13,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying assorted beverages, snacks and toiletries for her store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can continue to help her loved ones. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en: Corazon V.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She is 52 years old, widowed and has three adult children. She is from the village of Parug-Parog, Solana, Cagayan. Corazon has been in her business for over 34 years and earns approximately 70,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) every four months or during harvest time. In 2008, Corazon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 37,000 PHP from ASKI. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 45,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be her fifth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Kocha 33 Group

texts.en:
Mahboba is the group leader of Kocha 33 group.She lives in Kabul Afghanistan. She is married with two childern one son and on daughter they are 10 and 15.She is a quilt sewer. She can see different kinds of quilts with great designs and most of her neighbors like her way of work. Most of the time they tell her to sew quilts which are used for brides here as a custom. She wants to take a loan to purchase cloth and the other essential materials for her business.
She hopes to expand her business and to hire an employee to support her in her buisness.

loans.use: purchasing cloth and materials

loans.name: Thiem

texts.en: Mrs. Thiem V. is 61 years-old and lives in Tralach village in Takeo province.  She and her husband, Mr. Chhar Hang, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, they generate insufficient income to support the family living. So, Mrs. Thiem V. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike so her husband can become a motorbike taxi driver. With the loan, she hopes to increase their income and improve the family lifestyle. Mrs. Thiem V. has three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory and the other stays at home to do housework. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth J. is from the village of Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 47 years old. Elizabeth is married and has nine school-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from the buying and selling of bananas in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2008, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 46 years of age and is married with four children aged between 7 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She lives in her own two-room house and has the time and money to eat three meals a day. She takes care of additional family members.

Her three greatest expenses every month are paying electricity bills, school fees for children, and rent for her business premises.  Betty sells charcoal and raw food, mostly on a retail basis. She works seven days a week and serves about thirty customers a day. She has done this for business for four years now.

Betty's main challenges is that there are many retail shops that sell the same products as her.  She has been with Kiva field partner MCDT for six years now, and has borrowed twelve times.  She has had the same MCDT borrowing groupmates for five years now.  Betty wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal, and bunches of bananas and sacks of cassava and potatoes.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal and bunches of bananas

loans.name: Presfely

texts.en: Presfely U. is from the village of Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years old. Presfely is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Presfely makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Presfely has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Presfely joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Presfely has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Presfely is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Presfely from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Torn

texts.en: Mrs. Torn T. is 31 years-old and lives in Tonle village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Bros Loem, is a construction worker. Since her husband's job earns insufficient income to support the family, she decided to request a loan in the amount of 2,000,000 Riel from Kiva partner AMK to buy a motorbike for her husband to become a motorbike taxi driver. Mrs. Torn T. is the mother of three children who are all students in the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Encarnacion

texts.en: Encarnacion E. is from the village of Anakan, Gingoog City. She is 59 years old. Encarnacion is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Encarnacion runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Encarnacion has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 4,640 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Encarnacion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Encarnacion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. Encarnacion is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Encarnacion from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia H. is from the village of Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 47 years old. Alicia is married and has 2 adult-aged children. Alicia owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Alicia has been involved in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Alicia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Alicia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sovannary

texts.en: Mrs. Sovannary  P. is 40 years-old and lives in Tonle village, Takeo province. She is married with four children, one child is employed in a garment factory and the other three are students in the local school. Mrs. Torn Tuon is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from the plantation, she is a teacher in the local school and gets a little salary to support the family. Now, Mrs. Torn Tuon is asking for a loan to buy four piglets and a cow for breeding. She hopes this loan will help her increase her income and improve the family standard of living. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy four piglets and a cow.

loans.name: Vreneli

texts.en:
Vreneli S. is from the village of Anakan, Gingoog City. She is 45 years old. Vreneli is married and has 4 school-aged children. Vreneli owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Vreneli has been involved in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Vreneli joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vreneli has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Vreneli is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Vreneli from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nurkhon

texts.ru: Насимов Нурхон проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 50 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Насимов Нурхон имеет высшее образование. В области торговли работает более 10 лет. Насимов Нурхон арендует торговую точку. Он покупает и продает одежду и порфюмерию. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
N. Nurhon lives in the city of Kulob. He's fifty years old, married, has four children and a university education. He has worked in the field of trade for more than ten years, renting a trade point. N. buys and sells clothes and perfumes. He's requesting a loan to increase his goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario Y. is from the village of  Kinoguitan, Misamis Oriental. He is 30 years old. Mario is married and has 4 school-aged children. Mario owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Mario has been involved in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Mario joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mario is requesting his first loan from HSPFI, 4000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Norma's Group

texts.en:
Norma D. is from the village of Camanga, Dumalinao, ZDS. She is 45 years-old. Norma is the group leader of a two member group loan offered by Kiva partner PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Norma is married and has five school-aged children. Norma owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Norma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000.00 PHP a month.

In 2008, Norma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Norma is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Norma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Magadalene

texts.en:
Magdalene is 40 years of age and married, with five children aged 5 - 18. All her children go to school. Magdalene lives in a rented two room house where she stays with seven people. She has three meals a day and takes care of additional family members. Her three greatest expenses each month are the electricity bills, the children school fees and rent for her residence and business premises.

Magdalene has a stall in Nalukolongo selling charcoal and raw food such as bunches of bananas, cassava, sweet and Irish potatoes. She mainly sells on a retail basis. Magdalene works seven days a week and serves about twenty-five customers a day. She has been in this for business for four years now. Her main challenge is that there are many stalls that sell the same products as hers.  She has been in her business for ten years and with MCDT for six years, servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group mates for two years now. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal, bunches of bananas and sacks of cassava and potatoes.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal, bananas, sweet and Irish potatoes

loans.name: Phally

texts.en: Mrs. Phally T. is 26 years-old and lives in Tuol Kandal village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a two hectare field to cultivate rice. In this farm, she now faces a problem because her field does not have enough water to support planting. Therefore, Mrs. Phally T. is asking for a loan to hire a water machine to pump water to support the field. Her husband, Mr. Nein Som, is a laborer in the local village, who earns a small amount to support the family. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To hire a water machine.

loans.name: Adalat Semeteeva`s Group

texts.en:
Adalat is 50 years old. She has been married for more than 25 years and has 3 sons. Her husband and elder 2 sons work at a construction company in Russia and regularly send money to their family. Her youngest son is a high school student. Adalat has a very rare business for women in Central Asia; she is a taxi driver. She usually provides transportation services to her neighbors, friends and relatives. It all began in 2008 when she used money sent to her from Russia to buy a second hand Mercedes for $4000. At the present time, she earns about $150 per month. Last year she changed her car and bought a Toyota for $5000 because it is more comfortable and economical. She will use this loan to buy a tire and do some minor car painting. In the future, Adalat plans to find a constant job; previously, she worked in the city’s educational department.  

Mairamkan, 40, is a mother of five children. She breeds livestock and also sells milk products. She is trying to provide her children with the best education possible. She is planning to buy one cow to increase milk production. 

Idris, 34, provides transportation services. He is married with 4 children. His wife sells rice and his two older children are students. This loan will be used to buy additional rice for his wife’s business in order to increase turnover. 

Kizdarkan is 48 years old. She is a widow with 5 children. Kizdarkan breeds livestock. Her children also take an active role in this business.  Now she has 2 cows and will use this loan to buy a milk cow.  More milk means a bigger income for her family. 


This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-P's concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy a tire and do some minor car painting

loans.name: Khim

texts.en:
Mrs. N., 48, is a humble woman who currently lives with other family members in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She is married with four children. Two of her sons are employed: one is a taxi driver and the other works in Malaysia.  The remaining two children are going to school. 

Her husband helps to support the family by driving a motor taxi (he appears in the photo.)  N. is a requirement laborer. She gets many pieces of cloth from the garment industry and she prepares them as sets of each size for a fee (the cloth is used to upholster furniture.) 

N. has a son who is jobless and she proposes to encourage him to learn the skill of repairing mobile phones, but he is unable to pay the school fee. Because N. has no money, she decided to ask for a loan of $1200 which will allow her to both pay the school fee and to buy a computer for her school-aged children.

loans.use: To pay school fees and buy a computer

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene A. is a woman of courage to battle challenges in order to achieve her goals in life. She is 46 years old and married to Virgilio, 46, who is a fisherman. She is a caring mother of two children who are both of minor age. She lives in the coastal place of Talim Island, town of Binangonan, Rizal Province, in the Philippines. 

In 2007, she joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with an opportunity of having start-up funds for generating income. Since she received loans from ASHI, she carefully invested it in her fishing business and it gave her reasonable earnings. 

Now on her fourth loan, she requests 20,000 Philippine pesos for additional working capital for her fishing business. Specifically, the amount will be used to purchase a fishnet, rope, bamboo, fingerlings (young or very small fish) and labor expenses. She also plans to buy one motorboat to consistently visit their fish pond.

As a mother, Arlene dreams of sending her two children to school and on to completing college degrees and finding jobs for healthier lives. She also enjoys considering that the loan from ASHI will change their lives and provide her family's needs. She also dreams of building a big house for her family to live in.

loans.use: Purchase fishnet, rope, bamboo, fingerlings and pay for labor expenses

loans.name: Anipa's Group

texts.en: Anipa is the leader of this group. Anipa is 40. She has a big family that consists of her, her husband and four children. Anipa lives in the city of Karabalta, which is 60 kilometers to the west of Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. One of the main life priorities for Anipa has been to give all her children a proper education so that they have more favorable opportunities in their lives. To provide it, they saved their earnings and invested in purchasing a calf. Gradually, they increased the total population of livestock and began selling milk. Now, Anipa can boast about what a good household she and her husband together operate. Their eldest daughter has become a schoolteacher herself, and she is just 20. Two other children are still attending a secondary school. The little son is just 5 and stays at home by Anipa’s side. Raising livestock has been the main source of income for Anipa and her family for 25 years. And due to it, Anipa has been successfully raising her children and satisfying her daily needs. Recently, Anipa has applied for this loan. The reason for that is that for the rest of the winter season, Anipa urgently needs coal for heating her house. However, her monthly income of $73 does not allow her to make this purchase. Therefore, she hopes to obtain this loan and be able to buy coal. Anipa’s partners: Temirbek, 56, is the father of four children. His wife is unemployed. Temirbek is engaged in breeding cattle and selling milk. He needs a loan to buy a piece of land for his son. His son is married and needs to build his own household. Flyura, 43, is a housewife. She keeps a household and sells milk. Her husband works as a welder. Together they are raising five children. Flyura needs to obtain this loan to be able to attend a funeral of a close relative of hers. Dinara, 38, is a mother of five children. Her husband and elder children support the family by keeping sheep. They have applied for this loan to purchase furniture. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy coal for the rest of the winter season

loans.name: Leizel

texts.en:
Leizel M. is from the village of Brgy. Ibung, Villaverde Nueva Vizcaya. She is 25 years old. Leizel is single. Leizel owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food & daily use products in the local community. Leizel has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $86 US) for these activities.

In 2010, Leizel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Leizel is requesting her first loan from ASKI, in the amount of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is a mature gentleman who is 42 years old. He is married and has four children. He has a diploma and is a sophisticated person. 

He owns a camera shop. He has taken full advantage of his first loan and was able to make some changes to his his shop. His shop is in a convenient location adjacent to the Security Office. He bought a duplicator and other essential materials for his shop with his second loan. He now has permission to borrow more money from Al-Thiqa, because he is dependable. In addition to owning his shop, he also draws and takes photographs, as do his employees.

He purchased most of his merchandise by using the second loan that he received from Al-Thiqa. His income is now higher, which will enable him to bring up four children in tough circumstances. He always avoids being late in order to be a trustworthy customer. He has a acquired a lot of experience in his business.

loans.use: To buy a camera and copy machine

loans.name: Ol

texts.en:
Mrs. Ol H. is 27 years old and she is married with two children, one of whom is a student in the local school and the other is too young to study or work. Mrs. Ol H. and her husband, Mr. Pen Keo, are farmers who own a 1.9-hectare field to cultivate rice on to earn the family's living. This family lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province.

In order to support the field, Mrs. Ol H. needs 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to buy a pump; the rest of the loan she will use to dig a well to support the field. Aside from farming, she is a grocer and her husband is a laborer, who can earn only a small income to support the family. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a pump

loans.name: Kun

texts.en: Mrs. Kun P. is 54 years old and she is a widow with a child, who is employed in a factory. They both live in Tonle village, Takeo province. Mrs. Kun P. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice on to earn a living. Although she tries to work hard with her field, she still cannot improve the family's living conditions, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for breeding to increase her income and improve the family's living conditions, too.

loans.use: To buy two cows

loans.name: So

texts.en: Mrs. So S., age 36, earns a living by farming rice. She earns a fixed daily income of US$ 3 a day to help solve her family's financial problems. So S. has a partner in her husband who assists her in farming rice. The two are parents of five children who are teenagers and going to school. So S. built a stall behind her house where she plans to raise pigs. The daily profit of the family is not adequate to support them. Thus, So S. has applied for a loan to purchase piglets to breed and pig feed. She intends to use any remainder of the loan to buy an old rice milling machine to provide a service. So S. and her husband are pictured at their pigpen.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to breed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Biying a plot of land for construction

loans.name: Chan Thoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Chan Thoeun L. is 27 years old and she lives in Chong Angkar village, Takeo province. She lives with her spouse and they have two children, one of whom is a student in the local school; the younger child is 2 years old. Mrs. Chan Thoeun L. and her husband, Mr. Saem Soeun, are farmers who own 4-hectare field to cultivate rice on. In this farming, Mrs. Chan Thoeun L. needs 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to buy supplies for a pump, gasoline, fertilizer, and pesticide. She plans to use the rest of the loan to pay for laborers to dig a well to support the field. Aside from being a farmer, she is a scarf weaver who can earn a small income to support the family. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To buy supplies for a pump, gasoline, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Razel's Group

texts.en:
Razel M. is from the village of Baculod, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 31 years old. Razel is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Razel is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Razel owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Razel has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Razel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Razel has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Razel is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Razel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila M., of Teresa, Rizal Province in the Philippines. is a 40-year-old mother of two boys, both college students. A strong and courageous mother, she is married to Edilberto, a 41-year-old caretaker. She and her husband are active church members in their village.

As a woman of dreams, in 2005 she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), a Microfinance Institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since then, Leonila started a canteen (outdoor café) business that has really helped the family meet its educational and living expenses. Her previous loan played an important role in developing the business and subsequent increased business profits permitted the purchase of a motorcycle. Now she is requesting a new loan of 45,000 pesos as additional working capital to purchase more stocks for her canteen.

Leonila hopes that, with the help of ASHI and KIVA, she can achieve her main dream in life: sending her children to school until they find jobs. Leonila also extends her helping hand to her niece and nephew to bring them to school and make education their priority. She also dreams of a successful business, and even plans to have an Internet cafe in the future. Now, she says, her dreams are nearly within her reach.

loans.use: Additional working capital to purchase stocks for her canteen.

loans.name: Davaa

texts.en:
Davaa is a math teacher who lives with her husband and their 3- and 7-year-old daughters. She has lived in the city for the past eight years. She took out a clean-fuel loan to help her save money and to reduce air pollution in the city. Davaa said that the fuel “has many advantages, including the need to use less of it than regular fuel and that keeps us warmer. It is an especially nice opportunity for people who have a low income to purchase the fuel through a loan. By using this cleaner fuel, we use less fuel. For example, we previously had to burn extra fuel at night, but now we don’t need to do that because the new fuel burns longer.” 

About XacBank Eco Products Program

Ulaanbaatar is the coldest capital in the world. Winter temperatures can average -20 Celsius. Sixty percent of the city's population live in tents called gers, with wooden frames covered by layers of wool felt. On average, households located in the Ger Districts use 5 tons of coal and 1.5 tons of wood per year. Sixty percent of the pollution in the city during the heating season is attributed to coal burned in the Ger Districts. The bottom fifth quintile spend as much as 40% of their monthly winter income on heating fuels.

XacBank has worked with MicroEnergy Credits to launch a line of eco-products consisting of energy-efficient stoves and ger blankets, which will reduce energy consumption.

loans.use: Clean and energy efficient heating fuel

loans.name: Maïmounatou

texts.fr: Née en 1976 à Bassila dans le Nord du Bénin, L. Maïmounatou s’est installée depuis environs 20 ans au quartier Dandji à Cotonou, capital économique du Bénin. Maïmounatou est mariée à ALASSANE Ganiou, un commerçant, et est mère de cinq enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Seulement trois des enfants reste encore à la charge de Maïmounatou et de son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Maïmounatou n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Pour venir en aide à son mari, Maïmounatou a commencé la vente d’igname pilé (repas local apprécié des béninois), du riz et du haricot à Abattoir. Maïmounatou s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Il y a près de 5 ans que Maïmounatou a commencé par mener cette activité. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits auprès de l’institution, crédits qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Maïmounatou sollicite un sixième crédit pour renforcer son activité et mieux satisfaire tous ses clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1976 in Bassila (northern Benin), Ms. L. Maïmounatou got situated about twenty years ago in the Dandji district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Mr. ALASSANE Ganiou, a merchant, and is the mother of five children who are all in school. Only three of the children are still in her care and her husband's. The couple jointly ensures that family expenses are covered. Maïmounatou attended school primary school only. To help out her husband, she started selling pounded yams (a local meal appreciated by the people of Benin), rice, and beans, in Abattoir. She stocks up at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She started operating this business five years ago. She is a previous client of ALIDé having already benefited from five loans from this micro-finance institution. She has repaid all the loans. Facing the more and more numerous demands of her customers, Maïmounatou is requesting a sixth loan for bolstering her business and satisfying all her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of yams and rice

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda D. V., 48, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Alexis D. V., a construction worker, and they are blessed with three children. Merlinda makes sure to help her husband earn an income so that their family can have a better life.  She has been selling assorted cosmetics and clothes for four years.

Merlinda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow four times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy more products for her direct selling business, which lets her earn a profit of PHP 4,000 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying assorted cosmetic products and brand name clothes.

She dreams that her business will grow so that she can have enough resources for her children’s education. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy assorted cosmetic products and brand name clothes

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores S., 43, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Amancio S., a shoemaker, and they are blessed with two children. She makes sure to help her husband earn an income so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for 12 years

Dolores has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than two years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow three times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy stock for her business and help her husband in his shoemaking business. Both their businesses combined let them earn a profit of PHP 18,000 per month.  

Now with your help, Dolores would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying food stock for her store and materials for the shoemaking business.

She dreams that her business will grow so that she can send her children to school to have stable lives in the future.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy food stock for her store and materials for the shoemaking business

loans.name: Kristine Ivy

texts.en:
Kristine Ivy T. is from the town of San Fabian Echague. She is 27 years old. Kristine Ivy is single.  Kristine Ivy owns & operates a restaurant.  The main source of income for the business comes from serving specialty foods & delicacies to customers in the local community. Kristine Ivy has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $429 US).

In 2008, Kristine Ivy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Kristine Ivy from ASKI.  She successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from ASKI, which she used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. Kristine Ivy is requesting another loan of 50,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Food & drinks for a restaurant

loans.name: Barisiima Group, Central

texts.en: S. Juliet is 50 years old and married with four children; she also takes care of two orphans. Juliet is a businesswoman who has had a wholesale shop in Lweza for one year.  Although the business is faced with a lot of price fluctuations, she is able to make a 200,000 UGX weekly profit, which is mostly attributed to good customer care and the help of loans. Juliet dreams of ensuring that her business continues to grow and of having a prosperous family. Juliet needs a loan to be able to restock her wholesale shop with more goods.

loans.use: to buy more goods for her wholesale shop

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
Sharon F. is from the village of Casili, Mallig, Isabela. She is 28 years old. Sharon is married and has 2 school-aged children.  Sharon owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sharon has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $172 US) for these activities.

In 2006, Sharon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Sharon from ASKI.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Sharon is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product line.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William B. is 23 years old and married to Edna Jemutai, who is 24 years old. They have both been blessed with a one-year-old child called Kiptum Adams.

William runs a carpentry workshop which he started six years ago. The business gives him a profit of 20,000 KES and he gets an additional 15,000 KES from other sources of income. His workshop is at the heart of town so it is near clients, such as a bank, a hospital, supermarkets and other business premises, who need his services regularly.  

He has borrowed 20,000 KES from KADET Limited, which marks his first borrowing ever after having being introduced by other existing clients. He plans to use the loan to purchase timber. He anticipates earning a profit which will boost his business and also enable him to buy dairy cows.

B. dreams of owning dairy cows and keeping them on zero grazing. He describes himself as a hardworking, determined and honest man.

loans.use: to purchase timber stock for the workshop

loans.name: Good Hope Group, Central

texts.en: N. Imelda is a friendly and hard working single lady with four children aged 11 - 21; she also takes care of 2 orphans. She is a businesswoman involved in the sale of produce (cereals) for six years and although her business is faced with price fluctuations, she is able to make a weekly profit of 120,000 UGX. Imelda is grateful because the loans enable her to have good quality products. In the future, she needs to get a maize mill for business expansion and to enable her to educate her children to the highest level. Imelda needs a loan to be able to buy more cereals for resale.

loans.use: Buying more cereals for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying yams and corn

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Oeun R. cares for a school-aged child. To make a daily income, Oeun R. sews clothes in the garment industry and has a fixed salary of $90 per month. Another source of family income is her husband’s fishing business. He always leaves home with his gear such as nets and traps, which he uses to fish in and around the public ponds. 

Recently the amount of fish he catches has declined because he doesn’t have a boat to use. Therefore, Oeun R. is humbly requesting a loan of $800 USD which will allow her husband to buy a boat and some fishing equipment. Oeun R. and her husband are pictured at their house.

loans.use: To buy a boat and some fishing equipment

loans.name: Aminatou

texts.fr: Née en 1981 à Bassila, dans le Nord du Bénin, I. Aminatou vit depuis environs 18 ans au quartier Dandji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Aminatou est mariée à Zacharie, un chauffeur, et est mère de trois enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents à Dandji. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Aminatou n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Il y a trois ans, Aminatou a commencé la vente de produits cosmétiques de façon ambulante. Cette activité génère à Aminatou des revenus, qu’elle utilise pour subvenir à ses besoins et venir en aide à son mari. Aminatou s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu auprès de ALIDé, cinq crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Actuellement Aminatou éprouve des difficultés dans l’approvisionnement de ses produits. C'est la raison pour laquelle Aminatou sollicite un sixième prêt, afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle et aussi d’élargir son champ d’activité.
texts.en:
Born in 1981 in Bassila, in northern Benin, Ms. I. Aminatou has lived for about eighteen years in the Dandji district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Zacharie, a chauffeur, and is the mother of three children. All of the children are in school and live together with their parents in Dandji. The couple jointly ensures that family expenses are covered. Aminatou attended primary school only. Three years ago, she started selling cosmetic products door-to-door. This business generates revenues for her that she uses to meet her needs and to help out her husband. She supplies herself at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is a previous client of ALIDé having already obtained from ALIDé five loans, which were all repaid. Currently, she is exhibiting difficulties with her supply of products. For this reason, Aminatou is requesting a sixth loan in order to satisfy the demand of her customers and also to enlarge her field of business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying toothpaste, diapers, soaps, etc.

loans.name: Fernanda

texts.en:
Fernanda B., 43, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Gilbert B., a jeepney driver, she is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling food and managing her own variety store for six months.

Fernanda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT), a Kiva partner, for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow eight times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed for buying added stock for her store or ingredients for her food-vending business. Her businesses let her earn a profit of 15,000 Philippine pesos per month.  

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding businesses by allowing her to buy added stock for her store and ingredients needed for her food-vending business.

She dreams that her businesses will grow so that they will have an improved family life, finances for the education of her children and an improved house. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buying added stock for her store and ingredients needed for her food-vending business

loans.name: Samoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Samoeurn T. is 41 years old and she lives in Roneam Tnaot village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sombo T., are farmers who own 3 hectares (7.5 acres) of field on which they cultivate rice.

However hard this couple tries to work, they still earn less income than needed to support their family. In order to improve their living standards, Mrs. Samoeurn T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a plowing machine for her husband. He would use the plowing machine to plow their field and it will be hired by the villagers.

Mrs. Samoeurn T. is the mother of two children who are both students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy a plowing machine for her husband

loans.name: Twebaze Group, Mpigi

texts.en:
S. Sam is the leader of his lending group in Jjungo. He is 49 years old and married with six children, one of whom is still in school so he takes care of the other siblings. Sam is a businessman who has had a retail shop and a farming business for 10 years. From his businesses, he is able to earn profits that enable him to educate his children and take good care of his home. Sam needs a loan to be able to restock his shop with more goods, buy seedlings and employ labor on his farm. 

(In the small photo is a close up of S. Sam, who is also in the group picture)

loans.use: restock his retail shop, buy more seedlings for the farm and employ labor to help out on the farm

loans.name: Parwana Sameira Group

texts.en:
Bibi Sharifa is the group leader of Parwana Sameira Group. There are four members in this group.

Bibi Sharifa wants to take a loan for her husband’s business. He has a taxi for which he needs a new part and with the loan he would be able to solve this matter.

Samira and Shima want to take a loan for their business of carpet waving. They want to support their families and buy necessary materials for their business to improve it.

Nazarab S. wants to take a loan for his carpentry business. He needs to purchase more materials for his shop.

They have together requested a loan of 40,000 Afghani. They are glad of this loan process in Afghanistan because these loans help the poor people of Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy a new part for her husband's taxi

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
