Ann M. was born in 1972. She is a single mother to Alice Karim (17 years old,  just finished high school), Judy Jepchumba (15 years old, in Form Three in high school) and Edwin Kipyegomen (20 years old, finished high school awhile back). Ann lives in Kaptimbor village.

Ann is a second hand clothes trader and has been in this business for six years. The business gives her a monthly profit of about 50,000 KES but she also gets an additional 16,000 KES from other sources, including farming. Her business is situated within town.

Ann was introduced to KADET Limited by company staff and she had no previous credit history. She has borrowed a loan of 60,000 KES, of which she plans to use 20,000 KES to purchase mitumba (second hand clothes) for resale, 20,000 KES to purchase a piece of land and 20,000 KES to open a retail shop. With the extra profit she earns, she plans to get into the matatu (van transport services) business.

Ann has a great dream of opening a wholesale mitumba business. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing stock for her business

loans.name: Myriam Agossi

texts.fr: A. Myriam Agossi est née le 22 Septembre 1984 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Myriam Agossi s’est installée à Dandji à Cotonou, il y a près de 8 ans. Mariée à ZANNOU Blaise, un brodeur, Myriam Agossi est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. C’est avec ses enfants et son mari que Myriam Agossi vit. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Myriam Agossi a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et aux besoins de ses enfants, Myriam Agossi a commencé la vente d’œufs frais, depuis deux ans. Myriam Agossi mène cette activité de façon ambulante et s’approvisionne à Cotonou. Myriam Agossi a obtenu déjà un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé et qui lui a permis d’agrandir un temps soit peu son activité. La clientèle de Myriam Agossi s’accroît au jour le jour ; mais Myriam Agossi n’arrive pas à la satisfaire parce que les moyens financiers dont elle dispose actuellement sont faibles. C’est la raison pour laquelle Myriam Agossi sollicite un deuxième crédit pour renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
A. Myriam Agossi was born on September 22, 1984 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She became situated in Dandji in Cotonou nearly eight years ago. Married to ZANNOU Blaise, an embroiderer, she is the mother of two children who are both in school. She lives with her children and husband. The couple jointly ensures that family expenses are covered. Myriam Agossi stopped going to class in secondary school. To meet her needs and those of her children, she started selling fresh eggs two years ago. She operates door-to-door and stocks up in Cotonou. She has already obtained one ALIDé loan, which she repaid and which enabled her to expand her business for a time, short though it was. Her customers are growing day by day; but she isn't managing to satisfy them because the financial means at her disposal are currently limited. For these reasons, Myriam Agossi is requesting a second loan for bolstering her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying trays of fresh eggs

loans.name: Aoen

texts.en:
Mrs. Aoen U. is 43 years old and she lives in Phnum Lonteah village, Takeo province. She is married with three children, two of whom are students in the local school and the youngest one is 4 years old.

Mrs. Aoen U. and her husband, Mr. Doem Dey, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice. This couple tries to work hard but they still make less income than needed to support their family.

In order to increase their income and improve their family’s standard of living, Mrs. Aoen U. decided to ask for a loan to buy two hundred ducks for breeding to produce duck eggs to sell.

With her loans, Mrs. Aoen U.’s standard living is improving and her income is increasing too.

loans.use: To buy 200 ducks for breeding to produce duck eggs to sell

loans.name: Carmelo

texts.en: Carmelo A. is from the village of Parug-Parog, Solana, Cagayan. He is 50 years old, is married, and has three adult children. Carmelo owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Carmelo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. Carmelo is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his fourth from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Shamigul

texts.ru: Ахметова Шамигул проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 36 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Ахметова Шамигул торговлей занимается более 5 лет. Она продает женскую одежду. Кредит берет для увеличения товраоборота.
texts.en:
Shamigul A. lives in the city of Kulob. She is 36 years old, married and has 4 children. Shamigul has been involved in retail sales for over 5 years. She sells women's clothing. She is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Solange

texts.fr: A. Solange est née en 1968 à Parakou, au Nord du Bénin. Il y a 11 ans environs que Solange s’est installée à Djeffa dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à VODOUNNOU Josué, un policier, Solange est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Solange vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Djeffa. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la maison. Solange n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Depuis environs sept ans, Solange vend divers produits (farine de manioc, sucre, huile végétale, biscuits, lait, sardine, eau de javel, etc.) à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Solange s’approvisionne. Solange a bénéficié antérieurement de trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Malgré la passion que Solange a pour son activité, elle ne dispose pas d'assez de fonds pour mener à bien son activité et se faire plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses charges. Pour ce fait, Solange sollicite un quatrième crédit pour renforcer son activité afin de faire face d’une part à ses différentes charges, et d’autre part pour se faire une épargne consistante.
texts.en:
A. Solange was born in 1968 in Parakou, in northern Benin. About eleven years ago, she got situated in Djeffa, in the community of Sèmè-Podji in Benin. Married to VODOUNNOU Josué, a police officer, she is the mother of five children who are all in school. She lives together with her children and husband in Djeffa. The couple jointly ensures that house expenses are covered. Solange never attended school. For seven years, she has been selling a variety of goods (cassava flour, sugar, vegetable oil, cookies, milk, sardines, bleach, etc.) out of her home. Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she stocks up. She has benefited from three ALIDé loans before, which she repaid. Despite the passion she has for her work, she doesn't have enough funds for carrying out her work and for earning more revenues from it to meet her responsibilities. To do so, she's requesting a fourth loan for bolstering her business, so as to cope, on the one hand, with her different responsibilities and to built up, on the other hand, substantial savings.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cookies, vegetable oil, bleach, cassava flour, canned foods

loans.name: Duk

texts.en:
Mrs. Duk T., age 42, owns a plot of farmland where she plants a varieT. crops, including rice, morning glory, cucumbers and cabbage, that she sells when they mature. She has a partner in her husband who assists with her on the farm field. This couple has seven children, two of whom are married and the others are single. Three of their sons are construction laborers.

Duk T. and her family members always pay money for taxis because they do not own a vehicle of their own for traveling needs. In order to cut down on this expenditure, Duk T. is requesting a loan to buy a motorcycle which she will use for transportation.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to use for transportation

loans.name: Jonah

texts.en:
Jonah K. was born in 1976 and is married to Bornes Komen, who is a businesswoman. They have three children between the ages of 4.5 to 13 years old.

Jonah cuts and sells shoe soles but he also sells newspapers as a secondary business. He has been in the shoe business for 19 years. He earns a profit of 23,000 KES per month from all of his businesses. 

Jonah has borrowed a loan of 15,000 KES from KADET Ltd, which marks his first borrowing ever. He will use the funds to purchase more shoe sole materials for sale. He will use the extra profit to open a wholesale shop for shoe soles. 

Jonah dreams and hopes to purchase a plot and construct rental housing on it. He describes himself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: to buy more shoe sole materials

loans.name: Kasenge Kiguli Group, Mpigi

texts.en: N. Florence is the leader of her lending group in Mpigi. She is a hard-working and sociable lady with a business dealing in agricultural produce growing and selling produce in the markets in Kampala for 6 years. She is able to make 100,000/= as profit each week. Florence is married with 7 children all in school, and she hopes to educate all her children to the highest level as well as continuing to grow her business.

loans.use: Buying more agricultural produce for resale

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: Née en 1977 à Akpro-Missérété dans le département de l’Ouémé, K. Christine vit depuis sept ans à Agbalilamè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à NOUNAGNON Pascal, un chauffeur, Christine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Christine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Christine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a deux ans environs que Christine s’est mise dans la restauration. En effet, pour venir en aide à son mari, Christine vend des bananes frites ainsi que des taros frits, de façon ambulante. Christine s’approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Christine a obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien remboursé ledit crédit. Le stock de produits que vend Christine n’est plus actuellement suffisant pour satisfaire toute sa clientèle. De plus, Christine ne dispose pas suffisamment de moyens financiers pour augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux satisfaire toute sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Christine sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in en 1977 in Akpro-Missérété (Ouémé county), Ms. K. Christine has lived for seven years in Agbalilamè, in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Mr. NOUNAGNON Pascal, a chauffeur, she is the mother of four children, who are all in school. She lives together with her children and husband. The couple jointly ensures that family expenses are covered. Christine never attended school. About two years ago, she got started in food catering. To help out her husband, she basically goes from place to place selling fried bananas, as well as fried taro. She supplies herself at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She once obtained an ALIDé loan, and she repaid the aforementioned loan. The stock of goods that she sells is no longer enough right now for satisfying all her customers. In addition, she doesn't have the financial means to increase her stock of goods and to do better in satisfying her entire customer base. These are the reasons why Christine is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bunches of bananas and some taro

loans.name: Khit

texts.en:
Mrs. Khit S. is 62 years old and lives in Trapeang Roka village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chit Ros, are farmers who own a 2-hectare (5-acre) field on which they cultivate rice in the dry season. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

In this plantation, they now face some problems, because their field has infertile soil and has a lot of insects. Thus, Mrs. Khit S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to kill the insects. The rest of the loan she would use to buy fuel to support her water pump.

Mrs. Khit S. is the mother of one child who is a farmer and who helps on his parents’ field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer plus pesticide to kill the insects and fuel for their water pump

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. S. is a 30-year-old tailor with many years of experience in sewing clothing. She is a married mother of a child who attends primary school. She has a partner in her husband, who allows her to sew clothes. Mrs. S. buys pieces of fabric to sew into sets of uniforms for sale. She is also hired by neighbors to mend their clothes. Recently, Mrs. S. sold out her existing stock of clothing. She wants to buy more fabric, but she has no money. Thus, she has applied for a loan in order to buy more pieces of fabric to sew.

loans.use: To buy pieces of fabric to sew

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha M. is a 31-year-old farmer who lives in Kouk Roka village, Takeo province. She owns a 4 hectare field to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Leit Hang, is a cow middleman who earns a small income to improve his family's living conditions. Mrs. Sokha M. has four children: one is a laborer for a private company, two others are students at the local school, while the other is too young for school.

In her farming, Mrs. Sokha M. now faces some problems because her field has infertile soil and there is not enough water to support the rice field. She needs 2,000,000 riels from AMK to buy fertilizer, pesticide and fuel to support her rice field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and fuel to support a rice field

loans.name: Latofat

texts.ru: Одинаева Латофат проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 36 лет. Разведена, имеет 4 детей. Одинаева Латофат арендует торговую точку. В области торговли работает более 6 лет. Одинаева Латофат продает детскую одежду. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Latofat O. lives in the city of Kulob. She is 36 years old, divorced and has 4 children. Latofat leases a retail outlet. She has been working in the retail sales field for over 6 years. Latofat sells children's clothing. She is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Lelyn

texts.en:
Lelyn M. is from the village of Tagcatong, Gingoog City. She is 30 years old. Lelyn is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Lelyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lelyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lelyn is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Lelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Edmund's Group

texts.en:
Edmund G., from the village of Sto. Niño, Tumauini, Isabela, is the 36-year-old group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Edmund G..

Married with two school-aged children, Edmund owns and operates a specialized retail store whose main income comes from selling rice in the local community. Edmund has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, he joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edmund is now requesting a loan of 4000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, and he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his store.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Catherine

texts.fr: Née le 24 Mars 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, B. Catherine vit depuis 11 ans environs à PK10 Vivotin dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Catherine est mariée à SINDEHOU Pinus et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à PK 10. Catherine se joint à son mari pour assurer les charges de la famille. Catherine n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Il y a une dizaine d’année que Catherine mène comme activité, la vente de bouillie (faite à base de maïs et du sucre), accompagnée de pâtés (faits à base de farine de blé et d’huile). Catherine mène cette activité de façon ambulante et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Catherine a déjà obtenu auprès de ALIDé, un crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Actuellement, Catherine ne dispose pas assez de fonds pouvant lui permettre de satisfaire le grand nombre de clients et de se faire plus de revenus à la hauteur de ses différentes charges. C’est donc pour renforcer son activité que Catherine sollicite un deuxième crédit.
texts.en:
Born on March 24, 1977 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. B. Catherine has lived for about eleven year in PK10 Vivotin, in the community of Sèmè-Podji. She is married to Mr. SINDEHOU Pinus and is the mother of three children, who are all in school. The family lives together in PK 10. She joins her husband in ensuring that family expenses are covered. Catherine attended primary school only. For ten years, she has had a business selling porridge (made from corn and sugar) served with pâtés (made from wheat flour and oil). She operates this business from place to place. She stocks up at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She once obtained an ALIDé loan, which she repaid. Currently, she doesn't have enough funds allowing her to satisfy the large number of customers and to earn more revenues in line with her different responsibilities. And so, to bolster her business, Catherine is requesting a second loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying corn, wheat flour, sugar, and oil

loans.name: Phân

texts.en: Mrs. Phân D., age 47, is a local trader. She owns a shop inside the local market where she retails many types of shoes to earn a living. Phân D. was married but divorced her husband when her two kids were very young. Both of her kids are enrolled in school. Phân D. is very busy with her business activities due to there being many clients who need to buy her shoes. She sells well and recently she sold nearly all her items and she wants to acquire more shoes. Because Phân D. lacks capital, she requested a loan to increase the quantity of her inventory to continue selling.

loans.use: To increase the quantity of her inventory to continue selling

loans.name: Sikirath

texts.fr: T. Sikirath est née le 16 Mars 1972 à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Sikirath s’est installée, il y a près de 8 ans, à Tchonvi Ayimlonfidé dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Mariée à OUSMAN un soudeur, Sikirath est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble dans ce quartier. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la maison. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et venir en aide à son mari, Sikirath vend divers produits de beauté de façon ambulante. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Sikirath s’approvisionne. Sikirath mène cette activité il y a environs cinq ans. C’est la première fois que Sikirath sollicite un prêt auprès de ALIDé. Ce prêt lui permettra d’agrandir son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande de ses clients.
texts.en:
T. Sikirath was born on March 16, 1972 in Ekpè, in the community of Sèmè-Podji, in Benin. She got situated nearly eight years ago in Tchonvi Ayimlonfidé, in Sèmè-Podji. Married to OUSMAN, welder, she is the mother of two children, who are both in school. The family lives together in this district. The couple jointly ensures that house expenses are covered. To meet her needs and to help out her husband, Sikirath sells a variety of beauty products door-to-door. Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she stocks up. She has been in this business for about five years. This is the first time she has requested a loan from ALIDé. This loan will allow her to expand her business and to cope better with the demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying beauty products

loans.name: Darkhshan Reta Group

texts.en:
The pictured group is Darkhshan Reta which is made up of five woman. Torpeki is the group leader. She is 48 and married with five children. She wants to take out a loan for her husband’s house painting business. He needs a loan to buy the required, good quality materials for his business to progress well.

Shaperi is a good tailor. She sews kid’s clothes in her house. Most of her neighbors like her work and bring their children’s clothes to sew. She has received a loan to buy a new machine for her business. 

Semen has a beauty salon which is really popular in Afghanistan and is liked by most of the people. She wants the money to fill her requirements. 

Anetah wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a small cart parts shop. He would like to buy more materials for his shop.

The last member is Seveyta who would like to receive a loan for her brother who has a carpentry shop. She is confident that her brother will progress as soon as possible. 
 
They have requested a group loan of 70,000 afghanis and would like to thank the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To improve their businesses

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.en:
Ousmane B. is a thirty-year-old taxi driver in the Medina Fall neighborhood of Thies, Senegal's third largest city.

Ousmane has been a taxi driver since 2003, but says he has had trouble attracting clients, as his taxi is a bit run down. With the loan of 200,000 FCFA, he will fix up the car, including changing a door and repairing the hood. He hopes that with these reparations he will have more luck finding clients.

Ousmane is married, though he does not yet have any children. To supplement the income from his taxi business he raises goats, a popular side-business for many Senegalese.

loans.use: To repair his taxi

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 33 years old and married, and has one child. He is an educated person and a good bread-winner. He sells women's clothing.

When he received the first loan, he was able to build his own shop and purchase a lot of materials for his shop. As a result of his honesty and good  reputation, he was able to attract more customers, because all of his customers are women. He has an employee who helps him, and he intends to add more employees if his income increases. He bought a lot of women’s garments and gained a lot of customers. He is a good and dependable man to his customers and makes all of his loan payments in the proper manner.

loans.use: To buy clothing and materials

loans.name: Sieng's Group

texts.en:
Sieng S. sells a few vegetables that she buys from her wholesale supplier. She was born in 1963 and has been married for many years to Mr. Chin Reth, age 48. Her husband is a construction foreman. Together they make $7 per day. This couple has three young children who are studying and dependent on their income. Sieng S. is taking out her loan in order to earn extra income by purchasing secondhand clothes to sell at the market. 

This group loan has been applied for by three low-income people. Mrs. Sieng S. has been promoted by the other members of the group to be the leader. The other borrowers are: C., a fruit seller, who requests a loan to buy a motorcycle; and R., who works in construction and needs a loan to buy more building materials.

loans.use: To purchase secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet C. ia a 42-year-old member of ASHI who independently raised her four children who are presently aged from 15 to 20 years. After the loss of her husband fourteen years ago, she became both a mother and a father to her children. She fought poverty alone then.

Despite Juliet’s failure to sustain all of her children’s education until they graduated from college, she still feels happy that at least she has been able to sustain her second child’s education to a Bachelor of Science in Commerce and her youngest in third year high school.

Since the time Juliet became a member of ASHI, she has maintained a very good performance in her business, her repayments, as well as in her attendance every week at the center meetings. Now she is one of the active center leaders of the branch she belongs to.

Juliet sets herself as a role model for the rest of the members by utilizing her loan productively. Her previous loan of Php 10,000, which she used to finance her “sari-sari” (variety) store, has already been paid up and now she wishes to request another loan of Php 15,000 for the same purpose.

Juliet’s business is the greatest source of income for her family’s financial needs for food, education, clothing and medicine. Hence, she wants her business to grow into a grocery store that can provide her customers with access to their basic needs and increase her profits.

Juliet hopes that one day her dream of growing her business will come true and that her family will be able to enjoy an improved kind of lifestyle.

loans.use: To purchase additional items for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Fidèle

texts.fr: V. Fidèle est née en 1987 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Fidèle est mariée à DANMAMMI François, un commerçant, et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Fidèle vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Agbalilamè à Cotonou. En effet, le couple s’est installé dans ce quartier il y a trois ans environs. Fidèle assure, avec l’aide de son mari, les charges de la famille. Fidèle n’a pas fréquenté l’école ; et pour assurer ses besoins, Fidèle s’est mise depuis deux ans, dans la vente d’akassa (aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs). A côté de cela, Fidèle vend du riz et des pâtes alimentaires à son domicile, ce qui lui permet d’avoir plusieurs sources de revenus. Fidèle  avait bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. La clientèle de Fidèle s’accroît de jour en jour. Cependant, Fidèle manque de moyens financiers en ces périodes, pour pouvoir satisfaire tous ses clients. C’est ce qui amène Fidèle à solliciter un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin de mieux faire face à la demande des clients.
texts.en:
Fidele V. was born in 1987 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Fidel is married to Francois Danmammi a businessman and she is the mother of 2 school-aged children. Fidele lives together with her children and husband in Agbalilame, Cotonou. The couple have lived in this neighborhood for about 3 years. Fidele and her husband are able to meet the needs of the family. Fidele did not attended school and to make a living, she has been selling akassa (a corn based food) for the last two years. She also sells rice and food pates from her home which provides her with several sources of income. Fidele has benefited from a previous loan with ALIDe which she has duly repaid. Her clientele is increasing daily. She is missing the working capital during this period to meet customer demand. For this reason Filele is requesting a second loan from ALIDe to better meet this customer demand.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn and rice.

loans.name: Muborak

texts.ru: Абдуллаева Муборак проживает в районе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 43 года. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Абдуллаева Муборак имеет собственную торговую точку. В области торговли работает более 5 лет. Она продает концелярские товары. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Muborak A. lives in the Tursun-zoda district. She is 43 years old, married and has 2 children. Muborak has her own retail outlet. She has been working in the retail sales field for over 5 years. She sells office supplies. She is requesting a loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nanette

texts.en:
Nanette joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She likes it more because of its low interest rate and insurance.

Nanette is a 41-year-old married woman with six children. She started farming in 2000 and still continues to plant rice crops today. Her husband also works at a rubber plantation so that they have another source of income.

Nanette and her husband strive hard to provide their family with food, clothing and especially education for their children.

Nanette would like to request for a loan of Php 6,000. If granted, she will use the loan to buy farm supplies like seed and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
49-year-old Fe B. is one of the oldest members of the Bantayan center of ASHI. She aspires to bring her family out of the depths of poverty in her own way as a woman. She knew she had the potential to be productive and that push led her to join ASHI. 

Fe did not just value the loan she received from ASHI by utilizing it into growing a fish selling business. Through the training she has undergone, Fe has kept in her heart and mind the significance of the moral values that a person should posses once she is trusted. Because of this, since the first loan she received from ASHI, she has made sure that everything will fall into place and fulfill what she and her husband, who is the business with her, have planned for.

Not all of Fe’s five children. whose ages range are from 20 to 25, have graduated from college. Despite that, she still feels happy that at least all of them have been to college and two have graduated thanks to her business proceeds. She is happy not only because of the achievements of her family but also because of her ability to help other small-business people in her community.

The nature of Fe’s business is buying and selling fish. She has a stall in the town’s public market and her whole family are participating in her business. When fish is in season and Fe has a large amount of capital to purchase a large volume of fish, she ventures to trade in other municipalities and even in the neighboring province.

Little by little Fe notices her life has changed as her business progresses. For its sustainability and growth, she wants to request another loan of Php 45,000. With the continued support of ASHI and its partners as well as the support of her family, she is well on her way to achieve her dreams in life.

Fe believes that one day, she will completely become an entrepreneur.

loans.use: To purchase a large volume of fish to sell

loans.name: Eleanor

texts.en:
Eleanor R., is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Married to Edmundo R., a construction painter, she is blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling doormats and rags for several years.

Eleanor has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently.

Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, Eleanor was able to borrow six times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy raw materials for her rag-making business. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 3,200 per month.

Now, with your help, Eleanor would like to obtain a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying raw materials needed for making doormats and rags.

Eleanor dreams that her children will be able to finish their studies someday.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials needed for making doormats and rags

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is a 37-year-old married woman with a 2-year-old child. She is involved in rice farming and started this business way back in 1990. She wants to expand her 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm so she helps her husband to achieve this. She also raises pigs to add to their income.

Geraldine chose to be a member of CEVI because of its low interest rate. She is now requesting Php 6,000 which will be used for seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza, 43 years old, is the mother of five children. She married her husband, Felipe, in 1983. She ventured into farming in 1995 and still cultivates her 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm for rice crops.

Flordeliza wants to find other ways to earn, other than the farm, so she is able to provide for her family’s daily needs but right now she is focused on making the farm productive. She applied for a loan of Php 6,000 which she will use to purchase farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en: Zenaida recently joined CEVI to expand her business opportunities. She said she likes its program and sees it as a big opportunity for farmers like her who lack capital for their businesses. At 53, she still wants to provide for her family. She has six children with her husband Nestor. She wants to grow her farm so that even her grandchildren could benefit from it.  She would like to request for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos. She will use it to buy farm supplies for her rice farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Forty-five-year old Lilibeth is a married woman with four children. Her oldest child is 25 years old. She is involved in rice farming. There are also bananas and other fruit trees planted on part of her land. She sells these around her community to add income to her family.

Lilibeth is now applying for a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, a Kiva partner, which she will use to supply her farm with lacking inputs like seeds and fertilizers. She chose to be a member of CEVI because of its low-interest rate and insurance policy.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Alita

texts.en:
Alita is the mother of two children, her oldest child being 18 years old. Alita farms for a living and she currently has 2.75 hectares (approx. 7 acres) of rice field. This is where she earns income to buy food, clothes and her family’s other needs.

Alita is currently preparing her land for planting and said she needs seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI to buy the necessary items.

loans.use: To by seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita G., 43, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Married to Rafael G., a vegetable vendor, she is blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. Both of them have been selling vegetables for five years.

Anita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently.

Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, Anita was able to borrow four times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy more vegetables from suppliers. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 6,000 per month.

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business and used to buy assorted vegetables for her vegetable store.

Anita dreams that her business will grow so that they can buy a delivery truck for their produce and prays that God will bless their lives as one family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy assorted vegetables for her vegetable store

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa C., 57, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Jovencio C., a taxi driver, she makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been direct selling branded clothes and managing her own variety store for five years.

Elsa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow nine times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy stocks for her store. Her two businesses let her earn a profit of PHP 5,500 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying assorted snacks and beverages for her store and additional products for her direct selling business.

She dreams that her business will grow so that her youngest child can finish college and help all her children improve their lives. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy products for her store and direct selling business

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn tills a 2.25-hectare rice field. She started farming way back in 1989. She is 41 years old, married and has an eight-year-old child. She works hard at the farm because she wants it to prosper. She said that she still needs additional capital for the farm. She requested a loan of PHP 6,000 from CEVI. She will use it to acquire farm supplies that she needs.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Khady

texts.en:
Ms. Khady D. lives in the Medina Fall neighborhood of Thies, Senegal's third largest city. Her husband migrated to the U.S. to help support the family so Ms. D. takes care of their three children, aged 3, 6 and 12.

Two years ago, Ms. D. decided she wanted to participate in supporting the family financially and began selling fabrics and a local incense called thiouraye. With the loan of 150,000 FCFA, she will purchase a stock of thioupe (a colorful and highly sought-after fabric) and thiouraye to sell to her clients.

This is Ms. D.’s first loan.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and and incense to sell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita G. is a 48-year-old mother of two children who are 23 and 25 years old. She joined ASHI in 1996, wanting to achieve her dream of giving her children a better kind of life and rise above from poverty. Loans she had requested all throughout her membership had been very significant in changing her life and her family’s. Because of them, she has able to have a fishing and fish selling business as a source of her family daily finances as well as giving her husband a livelihood to manage. Anita’s husband is the one that manages the motor fishing boat she purchased through her previous loan from ASHI. She sells the fish in the market. When business capital and profits from the business are larger enough, she purchases a large volume of fish from other fishermen and trades them to other neighboring municipalities. Since she has paid up her previous loan, she requests a much larger amount of loan for the same purpose. Through this, her business will grow and eventually she will accomplish her dream of helping her husband support the needs of her children.

loans.use: To purchase another motor boat

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita M., 57, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Married to Mauro M., a church pastor, she is blessed with five children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been making and selling slippers for sixteen years.

Conchita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently.

Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, Conchita was able to borrow five times in CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to buy raw materials for her slipper-making business. Her business lets her earn a profit of PHP 15,700 per month.

Now, with your help, Conchita would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business and used to buy materials needed for making slippers.

Conchita dreams that her business will help provide the financial support that is needed for her son’s education in college.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her slipper-making business

loans.name: Confidence Sisters Group

texts.en:
This group of entrepreneurs named their group 'Confidence Sisters'. They are petty traders from the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each from SMT/Kiva lenders for the very first time in order to enable them to expand their businesses.

The leader of this group of 5 is Ejatu S.. The 40-year-old Ejatu is married to a businessman and they have 5 children – 2 in primary school, 2 in secondary school and 1 in nursery school. Ejatu has over 10 years of experience in the business world. She sells items such as soaps, toothpaste, batteries, biscuits, sugar, and many more. With this loan, she will buy more of these items wholesale to add to her current ones. (Beneath the photo are snapshots of two group members who were not present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy soaps, toothpaste, batteries, biscuits, sugar, and many more items

loans.name: Tamemsu Newsite Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'Tamemsu Newsite' group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 2,500,000 (or 500,000 each) from SMT/Kiva lenders for the first time in order to expand their businesses.

The leader of this group is Mamah K.. Mamah is approximately 50 years old. She is a wife and mother of 4 children. Three of her children are attending primary and secondary schools and the other is a businessman. For many years now (Mamah can not tell us exactly how many years now), she has been selling cooked rice, meat, fish, and vegetables. She also sells palm oil (the most popular cooking oil). With her share of this loan, Mamah will buy bags of rice and ground-nuts/peanuts so that she will be her own retailer. She will also buy gallons of palm oil and other cooking ingredients wholesale.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice and ground-nuts/peanut, gallons of palm oil, and other cooking ingredients wholesale.

loans.name: Maslandeneh Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Maslandeneh' group from the township of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. This will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses so that both sales and profit-to-sales-margin will improve. In this way, they will be in a better position to look after themselves and their children in terms of meeting their educational, nutritional and academic needs.

Baby M. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. She is a 37-year-old, born in Magburaka town. She is married to a businessman and the two of them have 3 children – 1 in Junior Secondary School II, 1 in class I, and the other not of school-going age. For more than 10 years now, Baby has been selling rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), ground-nuts/peanuts, and meat. With her share of this loan, she will buy a bag of rice, gallons of palm oil, and bags of ground-nuts to add to her business inventory.

(Beneath the picture is a snapshot of a group member who was not present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy a bag of rice, gallons of palm oil, and bags of ground-nuts to resell

loans.name: Nalpa Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Nalpa' group from the township of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each from SMT/Kiva lenders for the first time in order to expand their businesses. With the help of this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

Mariatu B. is the leader of this group. Mariatu is approximately 35 years old, married, and has 6 children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending school – 2 in Junior Secondary School II. (JSS II.), 1 in JSS I, 2 in class IV and 1 in class I. Mariatu has been a businesswoman for over 15 years now. She sells a variety of articles – batteries, soap, biscuits, plastic bags, etc. With her share of the loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items wholesale to add to her current stock of goods.

(Beneath in the photo is a group member who was not present for the group snapshot.)

loans.use: Buy batteries, soap, biscuits, plastic bags, etc

loans.name: Mariatou

texts.fr: Née en 1974 à Tchaorou au Nord du Bénin, L. Mariatou  est mariée à TAÏROU Djiman et est mère de trois enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés.  Mariatou s’est installée depuis quatre ans à Avotrou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle vit avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et assurer les charges de la famille, Mariatou vend de l’igname, de la farine de cossette d’igname et de charbon de bois à son domicile. Mariatou s'approvisionne à Tchaorou, au Nord du Bénin. Il y a près de 11 ans que Mariatou mène cette activité, et Mariatou a déjà obtenu quatre crédits qu'elle a bien remboursé auprès de ALIDé. Mariatou ambitionne renforcer son fonds de roulement et élever le niveau de son activité, afin de satisfaire la demande de plus en plus élevée de ses clients. C'est la raison pour laquelle Mariatou sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1974 in Tchaorou, in the North of Bénin, Mariatou L. is married to Djiman Tairou and is the mother of three children. All three children attend school. Four years ago, Mariatou settled in Avotrou in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, where she lives with her children and husband. The couple shares the family responsibilities. To meet her needs and to fulfill family responsibilities, Mariatou sells yams, flour made from yams, and charcoal from her home. Mariatou gets her supplies in Tchaorou, in the north of Bénin. Mariatou has been doing this type of work for nearly 11 years, and she has already received four loans which she has paid back to ALIDé. Her ambition is to increase her working capital and to raise her level of activity in order to satisfy the growing demand of her clients. This is why Mariatou is requesting a fifth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of whole and sliced yams

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn F., 47, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Married to Ireneo Coliseo, a businessman, she is blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own hairdressing salon for four years.

Jocelyn has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends the weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently.

Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, Jocelyn was able to borrow eight times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her salon business.

Now, with your help, Jocelyn would like to apply for a PHP 50,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business and used to buy equipment and to expand her salon business.

Jocelyn dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can have enough money for her sons’ college education. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment for and to expand her salon

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 57 years old and has 9 children. Despite his age, he is still active and brisk because he has worked as a the carpenter since he was very young.

He used this loan to purchase materials and supplies, such as, teak, plywood, hacksaws, and other tools that are essential to carpentry. Because of this loan, he was able to develop and expand his shop. He’s taken a huge benefit from this loan, including hiring a couple of employees to work with him, because he can’t manage all the tough work alone. 

He is such a trustworthy customer that he can borrow a loan whenever he needs one for his shop. His scheduled repayments were punctual and accurate as he repaid his debt. He has a good reputation in the market among his friends and that is another reason that he gets more and more customers in his shop.

loans.use: To buy wood and cutting tools

loans.name: Alima

texts.en: Alima S. is currently in the business of selling cereals like sorghum, maize, etc., and is requesting a loan to stock beans and pulses (groundnuts, peas, cowpeas) to sell. Alima is 18 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bigger store. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy beans and pulses to sell

loans.name: Apayi

texts.en:
Apayi S. is currently in the business of selling various items, such as biscuits and sweets, and is requesting a loan to stock bags of sugar, salt, and other items.

Apayi is 30 years old and is married with a husband that is a mechanic. She has one child and her child goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs, as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of sugar, salt, etc. to sell

loans.name: Daizy

texts.en:
Thirty-one-year-old Daizy O. lives in one of the very remote municipalities of Antique Province. In the small town of Libertad, with her three children, whose ages range from four to eight years old, and her loving husband, Daizy dreamed of having a life that is simply happy. Instead of focusing on negative thoughts and emotions brought about by poverty, as a mother and a wife Daizy knew that she served as the light for her family, especially for her children, to keep from succumbing to the trials of life. She tries to see opportunities that life can offer them beyond being poor. Though she discovered a lot, it was in 1997 when she found the greatest of all. That was when she became a member of ASHI, a Kiva field partner in the Philippines.

Through ASHI, Daizy has been able to obtain credit and has started her own small business. Over time, the loan amount she qualifies for has increased, as her hog-fattening business has grown. The larger the volume of hogs she sells (either alive or slaughtered--the pork is sold per kilo after four months of fattening), the more she profits. Daizy's business proceeds since then have been a great provider of food and other basic commodities her family's needs. She is no longer dependent on her husband’s sporadic and small income; instead she takes part in earning money.

Daizy has been so happy with her achievements since obtaining membership in ASHI because she feels that she has helped not just her family but also people who live in their inaccessible village. The pork and pigs she sells has brought people convenient access to food. Therefore, Daizy would like to request another loan, which she will use for growing her business. That way she will be able to increase the number of hogs she is raising and selling, and increase the profits which improve her family's lifestyle.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to fatten and re-sell.

loans.name: Sirodjiddin

texts.ru: Абдулмаджидов Сироджиддин проживет в районе Вахш. Возраст, 38 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Абдулмаджидов Сироджиддин растениеводством занимается более 12 лет. Он выращивает разные виды растений. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Sirodjiddin A. lives in the Vakhsh district. He is 38 years old, married and has 5 children. Sirodjiddin has been involved in horticulture for over 12 years. He grows various types of plants. He is requesting a loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a 41-year-old married man, who has four children in school. His business is named Eastlanders Auto Care, where he provides mechanical and panel beating services. He has employed two people. His business is favored because it is located along a busy road with heavy traffic. He has been running the business for 15 years and previously used to do sugarcane farming. Faulu Kenya has helped his business expand and gain customers. Peter has requested a 40,000 KES loan so as to buy a compressor machine and assorted tools. His hope is to set up a large business. He describes himself as dedicated to a better future.

loans.use: To purchase a compressor machine and assorted tools

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene G. is a woman with determination to rise above poverty. She is 56 years old and the widowed mother of four children, all of whom are of legal age already. She lives in Coastal Talim Island, town of Binangonan, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

In 2007, she decided to join Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, to obtain capital for her sari-sari store (general store). During her membership in ASHI, her performance has been recorded to be very good. Now she is requesting a loan of 20,000 pesos to pay for 50 sacks of charcoal, liquors and other groceries for the store.

With the help of ASHI and Kiva, she believes that she will rise up from poverty. She said that the services of ASHI and Kiva offer big opportunities to make their family dreams come true.

loans.use: To pay for 50 sacks of charcoal, liquors and other groceries for the store

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn V. is 46 years old. She is married to Mr. Emeterio V., who is a fisherman. The couple has an only child, Diane Camile, who is a 15-year-old high school student.

Since her husband's income is not enough to sustain the daily needs of their family, she joined ASHI in 2007 because she wanted to have an expanded business and get closer to the fulfillment of their dreams.

She and her husband aim to continue to develop a stable business so they can support the education of their daughter and have their own big home. Now on her fourth loan, she is seeking 20,000.00 Philippine pesos. The loan funds will be specifically used to pay for one motor boat, a bubo (shrimp catcher), one sack of fish feed and two rolls of rope for her fishing business.

She hopes to have a successful business, dreams for a brighter tomorrow and to be away from the ties of poverty.

loans.use: Pay for one motor boat, a bubo (shrimp catcher), a sack of fish feed and two rolls of rope for her fishing business

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline A. is a 34-year-old woman with a strong faith to get away from the ties of poverty. She is a loving mother to three children who are all of minor age. The oldest is only 11 years old and the youngest is a nine-month-old baby. She is married to John Arnold, an electrical reliever. Her husband's salary is insufficient for their daily expenditures.

As a woman of courage, in 2007, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), a Microfinance Institution and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since obtaining a loan from ASHI, she started a fishing business and it truly helped them to sustain their needs.

Now for her fourth loan, she proposes the amount of 20,000 PHP to pay for five packs of nylon rope, fishnet, bamboo, fingerlings (small fish) and labor expenses to construct a fishpond.

She hopes that, with the help of ASHI and KIVA, she can reach her goals of a bigger fishing business, support her children's education and fight poverty.

loans.use: To construct a fish pond.

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en: Boniface is a 40-year-old married man.  He has a daughter and son who are in school.  His wife is a hairdresser. He has been running a butchery for five years in the Kwa Njenga slums in Nairobi.  He employs three people.  He was previously employed and he currently earns extra income from the salon that his wife runs.  He requested a loan of Kes. 50,000 to buy more beef for his butchery.   He hopes to someday own rental houses and expand his business to a wholesale supplier.  He describes himself as hardworking, honest and kind.

loans.use: To purchase more beef.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby G. is 36 years old. She lives in Coastal Place on Talim Island, Binangonan, Rizal, Philippines with her husband and four children. She and her husband, Mr. Efren, have not finished their studies at college because neither of their families could afford to pay for their education. The couple is working hard to give a better education to their children and they want a better life as well.


They decided to join ASHI in 2007 to get capital for their fishing business. They have requested a new loan of PHP 20,000. They will invest this capital to buy their own pump boat, 20 pcs. of bubo (shrimp catcher) and fish feed.


She hopes to build their own dream house, expand her fishing business and to have more room for their fishing materials. She is grateful to the ASHI and KIVA partnership that provides loans that contribute to changing their lives.

loans.use: To buy a pump boat, bubo(shrimp catcher) and fish feed.

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: Monsieur Mamadou N. demeurant à Thiès Médina Fall est mécanicien de formation  depuis 5 ans. Il travaille actuellement  dans une usine de cimenterie sise dans la région de Thiès. Agé de 33 ans, Monsieur N. vit avec sa femme, maman et sa fille de 4 ans dans sa maison en cours de finition. Cependant après un crédit  auprès d’U-IMCEC qu’il a entièrement réglé, Monsieur N. souhaite un autre financement, toujours pour les travaux au niveau de sa maison. Ainsi, il demlande un prêt de 200 000 FCFA pour acheter du ciment afin d’achever la construction d’une chambre et d’assurer  les finitions au niveau de sa véranda.
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou N. lives in Thiès Médina Fall and has been a trained mechanic for 5 years. He currently works in a cement factory located in the region of Thiès. He is 33 years old and lives with his wife, mother and four-year-old daughter in his house which is in the process of being built. After receiving one loan from U-IMCEC, which he has completely repaid, Mr. N. wishes to secure another loan for improvements to his house. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of 200,000 FCFA to buy cement in order to complete the construction of a bedroom and to finish work on his veranda.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cement to complete work on his house

loans.name: Ibrohim

texts.ru: Абдуллоев Иброхим проживает в районе Вахш. Возраст, 51 год. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Абдуллоев Иброхим занимается растениеводством и плодоводством более 30 лет. Он сажает арбуз и разные другие виды растений. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений и плиёнки для парника.
texts.en:
Ibrohim A. lives in the Vakhsh district. He is 51 years old, married and has 4 children. Ibrohim has been involved in horticulture and crop production for over 30 years. He plants watermelons and other types of plants. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers and greenhouse plastic.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers and greenhouse plastic

loans.name: Furkat

texts.en:
A. Furkat is 31 years old and is not married. He is a very diligent and hard-working man who uses his car to provide taxi services. Furkat’s usual itinerary is Kanibadam-Khujand.

For the last two years Furkat’s business had been the main income for the family allowing him to improve the living conditions of his large family. Currently, his daily income is about 80-100 Somoni.

As any business generating income, Furkat’s business also requires some investment from time to time. Thus, now the car needs a thorough overhaul. For this reason he requests 1,500 USD. He promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all those supporting him.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit:  www.imon.tj

loans.use: To pay for a thorough overhaul of his taxi

loans.name: Shamsubonu

texts.en: B. Shamsubonu is 38 years old and is married with two children of school age. Shamsubonu sells the fabrics used for sewing the national dresses and has been in this business for almost five years. She has very good taste and she is ready to advise her clients which textile to choose for this or that occasion. That is why she has her regular customers. Moreover, Shamsubonu’s prices for fabrics are attractive for various levels of the population as she has a wide range of goods for any taste and any wallet. The income that Shamsubonu derives allows her to educate her children. She hopes that she can continue to provide for them so they will be able to receive an adequate education. Now, Shamsubonu needs 5,000 Somoni to purchase new fabrics in order to increase the range of her goods. She promises to repay the loan without any violation and expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her. Your generosity can change her family’s life. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new fabrics in order to increase the range of her goods

loans.name: Christophe Latyr

texts.fr:
Monsieur Christophe Latyr N. est agent de sécurité en fonction dans une agence de la place. Mais au paravent, il s’activait dans l’agriculture qu’il cumulait avec de l’embauche bovine. Monsieur N. est  membre d’U-IMCEC où il a domicilié son salaire. Ainsi il peut solliciter des prêts sans demande  des  garanties au préalable.
Célibataire agé de 30 ans, Monsieur N. compte accroitre ses revenus en s’auto employant. C’est ainsi qu’il demanda un prêt de 150 000  FCFA pour  relancer son embauche bovine. Avec cet argent, il veut acheter un bœuf qu’il va commercialiser à l’occasion du Gamou ou Maouloud  (célébration de la naissance du prophéte Mouhamed Paix et Salut sur Lui), une fête très suivie au Sénégal et programmée vers la fin du mois de Février.
texts.en:
Mr. Christophe Latyr N. is a security guard who works in an agency in the area. Beforehand, however, he was active in agriculture which he combined with beef fattening. Mr. N. is a member of U-IMCEC (a mutual savings and loan association) where he places his salary. As a result he can apply for loans without putting up any guarantee. Single and 30 years old, Mr. N. is planning on increasing his income by becoming self-employed. For this reason he asking for a loan of 150,000 FCFA in order to relaunch his beef fattening activity. With this money he wants to buy an ox which he will sell at Gamou or Maoloud (a celebration of the birth of the prophet Mohamed - may peace and blessings be upon him), a very popular festival in Senegal which takes place towards the end of February.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase an ox to sell on

loans.name: Mukhtorjon

texts.en:
B. Mukhtorjon is 37 years old. He is married and has two children. Mukhtorjon has a specialized secondary education. He works hard to cultivate his products, which are as wheat, onions, carrots and other vegetables. He works from early morning until late at night, hoping to have a rich harvest. 

Mukhtorjon sells his products in the market where they are always in high demand due to their good quality. He also raises cattle. His work fills him with great optimism and allows him to help his beloved children. His goal is to improve the quality of his agricultural products even more and to grow his business. 

Today Mukhtorjon is requesting a loan of $1100 to buy greater quantities of fertilizer and also some young cattle. Let's help Mukhtorjon as he works hard to improve his family's quality of life.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and young cattle

loans.name: Umeda

texts.en:
B. Umeda is 35 years old, married and has three children. She works with her husband, purchasing and reselling cows. Umeda would like to request a loan of 4,000 TJS in order to purchase additional cows to increase her inventory and meet customer demands. She believes this will lead to greater revenue and, ultimately, greater profit for her family. 

In the future, Umeda would like to reinvest the earnings generated by this loan back into her business to purchase more cows and increase their income further. They plan to use the increased income to fund their children’s education. You could become an important part of Umeda's family's life. She deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving her.

loans.use: To purchase additional cattle to expand her business.

loans.name: Ninfa

texts.en:
Ninfa T. is 34 years of age and is a new member of ASHI. She is married and has five children, whose age range is from 12 to 20.  Ninfa joined ASHI hoping that by having her own business, and with the use of a loan, she could make her dream of a better life for her family come true. She is now qualified to receive a second loan through ASHI after successfully repaying her previous loan.

The first step she took to achieve her aspirations was to partner with her husband in his fishing business. Since her husband’s livelihood is their main source of daily income, she wants to support its growth. She wants to provide for the needs of her children, especially those who have not gone and those who cannot go to college. Ninfa knows that their having a better paying and stable job anchors on the income from the business. 

Presently, Ninfa is not yet profiting a great deal from their business because her husband is not in control of his fishing schedule. He only borrows his neighbor's fishing boat when it is not in use. As a result, Ninfa can sell the fish and make an income only on an irregular basis. 

Ninfa is requesting a much larger loan so that she can buy a fishing boat for her husband. Once they have their own boat, they can improve their income and better provide their children’s needs.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat for their fishing and fish-selling business.

loans.name: Karim

texts.en:
H. Karim is an agricultural producer who has been working in this sphere of business for eleven years. He is a family man and feels responsible for supporting his three children who need help with their education. His wife is a very hardworking woman who also supports him in his production activities in order to improve their lives and be able to go on with their family life. 

Aware of the needs his family is going through, Karim requested and received a loan from IMON International three years ago. He used that loan to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer for his harvest. Karim comes to IMON International today again to ask for a loan that may allow him to go on with his business and give his very beloved family the support they deserve.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Sharifkhudja

texts.en:
H. Sharifkhudja is 26 years old. He lives in Isfara town. Sharifkhudja processes and sells dried fruits in the local central market. He is experienced in the business of making dried fruit. He purchases fruit from local farmers at a wholesale price, and after processing sells it to his customers. 

Because Sharifkhudja buys his goods wholesale, his prices are lower than regular market prices. He offers a wide assortment of goods for clients of different means. All this allows Sharifkhudja to make his business quite successful and it brings in a stable income for his family. 

Currently, he needs a loan of $1200 to buy supplies so he can continue to offer a good product to his customers. Sharifkhudja expresses his gratitude to everyone supporting him.

loans.use: To buy supplies for his dried fruit business.

loans.name: Muhiba

texts.en:
Muhiba has sold fabrics for women’s clothing at the market for many years. Her fabrics are some of the best at the market and by now she has many clients. Muhiba knows her business very well.

Muhiba is married and has four children. Her husband works in agriculture.

Muhiba wants to borrow money to purchase more goods to sell and thus have more profit. With that profit she will be able to provide better living conditions for her family.
